Cq Roll Call And Georgetown University Holds Discussion On Fintech, Cryptocurrencies And Clearinghouses

June 12, 2019 05:00 Pm

SPEAKERS:

EUROPEAN SECURITIES AND MARKETS AUTHORITY CHAIR STEVEN MAIJOOR

FINTECH BEAT CO-FOUNDER CHRIS BRUMMER

INSTITUTE OF INTERNATIONAL FINANCE DIGITAL FINANCE SENIOR DIRECTOR BRAD CARR

CHAMBER OF DIGITAL COMMERCE CHIEF POLICY OFFICER AMY DAVINE

KIM POST OAK LABS FOUNDER TIM SWANSON

CQ ROLL CALL PUBLISHER JOSH RESNIK

[*]RESNIK: Good evening, and thank you for joining CQ Roll Call, Georgetown University Law Center, and the Institute for International Economic Law, for a discussion on FinTech, Cryptocurrencies and Clearinghouses. My name is Josh Resnik, and I'm the publisher of CQ Roll Call, as well as the emcee for today's event.

Before we kick off the discussion, I'd like to take a moment to set the stage for this evenings dialogue. Today, we live in a world of rapid change. Every industry is going through turbulence and transformation, largely driven by technology, but also by political and governmental changes as well, and finances is clearly not immune. Technological changes are upending the industry. Today, we call those changes by the collective name of FinTech. But as Georgetown's own Professor Chris Brummer has said many times, in 5 or 10 years what is now called FinTech will simply be the new world of finance.

At CQ Roll Call for the past 75 years, our publications have been leaders in unbiased, nonpartisan, legislative, and regulatory analysis. And now, in partnership with Professor Brummer, we're launching new coverage of FinTech's technological and regulatory impacts. We'll be teaming up with regulators, academics, and industry leaders to elevate the public's understanding of modern finance. We've been excited to partner with Professor Brummer on this coverage, including our new podcast, FinTech Beat, which went live on Apple today. And we're also delighted to be partnering with Georgetown Law School and the Institute of International Economic Law on tonight's event.

So let's dive in and get started with our panel. Professor Brummer will be moderating tonight's discussion. In addition to being a professor here at Georgetown, as well as the co-founder of FinTech Beat, Chris is also a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's Subcommittee on Virtual Currencies and a member of the Consultative Working Group for the European Securities and Markets Authority's Financial Innovation Standing Committee.

We're fortunate to have some of FinTech's leading experts joining us on our panel this evening. So please join me in welcoming Brad Carr, senior director of Digital Finance at the Institute of International Finance. Brad leads the IIF's analysis on technology and innovation issues, including data regulations, reg tech, cloud, and distributed ledger technology, and the IIF's studies on the adoption of machine learning within the financial sector.

Next, we have Amy Kim, chief policy officer at the Chamber of Digital Commerce. Prior to joining the chamber, Amy advised financial institutions, blockchain-based companies, marketplace lenders, investors, and innovators regarding compliance obligations under financial services laws.

Our third panelist is Tim Swanson, founder and director of Research at Post Oak Labs. Tim is currently an advisor to Elm Labs, Clear Maddox, and Bloxier (SP), and was an advisor to Hyperledger.

Please join me in welcoming our panelists and CQ Roll Call and Georgetown's own Chris Brummer to the stage.

(APPLAUSE)

BRUMMER: So thank you so much. Afterwards, we're going to have a--a brief opportunity for a--a Q&A, both with our panelists, and also, obviously, for our--our--our keynote discussion later.

There's nothing like having an event after alcohol and having some introductory drinks. And hopefully, this will--will help to get the most forthright and interesting conversation from all of our panelists.

RESNIK: We--we didn't get to do the drinking though.

BRUMMER: Oh, yeah. Well, fortunately, I did.

(LAUGHTER)

We prepared the audience for us.

BRUMMER: I guess that's the most important thing.

So I guess I'll start with--with you, Tim. You know, some of the biggest news recently, particularly when you're talking about cryptocurrencies, and stable coins, and new applications for distributed ledger technology, has come from the entrance of new kinds of players but they're new familiar players, particularly big tech, and big finance with this announcement, both by JP Morgan and Facebook, that they are entering into this space. And there's a--a lot of talk and a lot of buzz about this really reshaping the cryptocurrency landscape. Maybe, could you sort of help walk us through what exactly are the kinds of things that they're looking to do and--and why is it that they're interested in--in blockchain technologies more generally?

SWANSON: A quick question, who's--who works for JP Morgan, anyone here or Facebook. All right.

So yeah, the two that I guess I'll mention, and thanks for that, are JPM Coin. I know it's been mis-characterized by some calling it Diamond Coin, and some people aren't excited about it. That's fine. You don't have to be excited about it. I'm not here to shill--shill the coin or anything like that. But what--what's--what's--the reason why JPM Coin was created is--is a means to an end. They needed a way internally, or on this--this network that they created called IIN, they needed a way to--to effectively settle these different instruments that they may have created on behalf of whatever participants on the network, rather than having to rely on the outside, effectively the settlement rails that takes three to five days. So if you have unchained cash then you can provide effectively instant settlement and therefore, get rid of the--this locked up capital.

For example, if you look at the nostro vostro accounts globally, as an aggregate in the world, it's like $9-$10 trillion of capital is sitting there at any given time. So, you know, obviously, JPM Coin's not going to revolutionize that entire--

BRUMMER: --So let me just--just--just jump in, just to make--make sure.

SWANSON: Sure.

BRUMMER: So what you're basically saying is, JP Morgan has customers. They need to service those customers. And by creating a new kind of rail they're able to allow some of their existing customers to settle their transactions faster. Or is it--is it faster? Is it supposed to be more--more--better security? You know, what--what is it that creating JPM Coin does that an Excel sheet wouldn't be able to do?

SWANSON: Sure. So that's a great question. As it of this--as it of this moment, in June, it looks like the you know, you could have an Excel--Excel chain, if you will, that would be just as effective because you're effectively relying on that one participant. In theory, though, the--the goal for them long-term is to enable other participants to potentially validate transactions on the network or even open to the network to--to other--other networks. In fact, the long-term goal for them, my understanding, is for them to--to actually allow retail participants and not just wholesale interaction.

So again, it's a means to an end. It's kind of, I hate calling it boring inter-bank related activity, but it is. It's--it's not something that you and I as--as its consumers would probably ever touch in the next couple years. Whereas, the Facebook phenomenon, which you were kind of mentioning, I believe, since they've taken all their data, now he wants to take all of money.

(LAUGHTER)

So for what it's worth, Facebook Coin, they--they're supposed to do some announcement, I think, on the 18th or so when they review all the information and until then, we can only speculate based on what we've heard. But what we've heard so far is it's going to be some--like a basket of--of currencies, kind of like an SDR, which is a basket of--of four or five different major currencies. So it's kind of a stable coin. We've heard that maybe the network participants are going to be charged up to $10 million to run nodes. So the--the model is very different than JPM--JPM Coin, which is kind of a means to an end for the--its customers and counter-parties, whereas Facebook Coin sounds like it's, or sorry, Global Coin I think is what they call it, is going to be, supposedly, for--for remittance market, for participants who are--for--for the billion plus users that they have to move money across borders.

BRUMMER: So ultimately, we're talking about two very different financial products, if we are to believe current reports. That on the one hand, you have Facebook, which is apparently going to leverage some of its messaging for its retail-ish people, normal people. And then you have Facebook Coin, which is looking to, at least immediately, service institutional investors and to service those institutional investors by establishing a--a new rail, a new means of transacting cross border. But I guess both of them have a cross border feel to it, right? I mean, because JP Morgan, I'm guessing, has lots of different banks and then you have Facebook, which has--is going to lever this messaging system for all of its billions of users.

And I will get to, for that question, Brad. Maybe if you could maybe elaborate some of what you've heard or--or thought about in terms of these new financial products or stable coins--

CARR: --Sure--

BRUMMER: --and--and also, any kinds of immediately or immediate regulatory questions (INAUDIBLE)?

CARR: So I think, firstly, you know, if I can distinguish another model as well, and that's that of--of MUFG Coin, which I think is probably the most advanced of the--the prototypes we've seen around the world, whereas the JPM Coin is targeted in the--the wholesale sector. It's about, you know, it's the settlement of transactions for--for corporate counter-parties, whereas MUFG Coin is a lot more retail oriented. Yet MUFG's own marketing is that if you go to Tokyo for the Olympics next year you'll be paying for your meals around town with--with MUFG Coin.

You know, that notion is more one of its trying to modernize a retail payment or point of sale transaction. It's essentially enabling you to have tokens of some sort on your phone and paying with those as an alternative to cash. And the Bank of Canada prototype for a--a central bank digital currency, is essentially working towards the same sort of model. So you've got a few different variances there.

The--the scenario that--that I came up against on the JP Morgan one is, that I think is going to get really interesting is, so what happens when you end up with one bank holding another banks coin? You know, if--if, let's say Citibank is holding a JPM Coin, is that equivalent to holding JPM senior debt in terms of the credit risk profile? Or is it considered to be cash back because it's reserved? Are you convinced of the--the stable coin fixing? Or do you start to say, "Well, actually, this is a different kind of risk profile?" And then similarly, if a customer is given JPM dollars and getting JPM coins back, you know, from a--a ledgers perspective of--of how you assess that counter-party risk, are you knitting the--the dollars and the coins?

So you've got a few things there that--that I think are all manageable issues, but are ones that, in terms of the prudential framework, you'd need to work through which of those and establish whether or not this is essentially considered equivalent to, you know, coins and bank notes under the existing prudential framework.

BRUMMER: That's--that's--that's interesting. One of the things that I--I noticed when you travel, obviously, to different international regulatory fores (SP), how people look at it, particularly a stable coin, but also any kind of cryptocurrency depends on where they're coming from. So for those who may not be as familiar with the stable coin, they're called stable coins because they're--they're presumably pegged or reference to a--a certain basket, or perhaps even the U.S. dollar and they're not intended to fluctuate. And the way in which you can create that stability is--is varied at least.

CARR: Yep. Right.

BRUMMER: And--and some of those ways can be just a straight peg or they could be algorithmic activities.

CARR: So--so if--so if you're a regulator trying to work out a prudential treatment that you're going to apply to this, one of the questions you'd need to establish is, you know, are you convinced of the--the peg? Or is this something that, you know, okay, it's fixed today but it may--may well not be in the future?

And to segue a little from the commercial bank tokens, you know, one piece we've--we've heard and we've corroborated in a few different places, is that the People's Bank of China has been developing a digital currency that would not be fixed against the renminbi. Now, there's a whole host of questions then that come to--to buy with that. You know, is that intended to segregate inward and outward capital flows away from the other currency? Is it something that's intended as a means of a--being a trade--international trade currency, or trade finance currency? Will Chinese industrialist in 10 years time insist that they're only going to pay you in--in digital renminbi instead of in dollars?

You know, there's a whole stack of questions that come about there for something that presumably would be, you know, somewhat stable, not entirely volatile. Presumably, the PBOC would have an interest in ensuring that that currency is--is not wildly fluctuating day to day and it retains some of its value, but it would not be fixed against the renminbi in that example.

BRUMMER: And--

CARR: --Yep. So if I can make one more point. And well, you referred to Facebook, and you referred to the different treatments and definitions around the world. You know, the scenario I find really fascinating is, you know, are yourselves going to have individuals giving Facebook dollars in order to buy Facebook coins, or whatever it's called? When we get around and--and have the conversations with central bankers and regulators around the world, and we talk about, you know, "Would you view the entrance of a big tech firm into finance?"

You know, at what point do you start regulating them in the same way that you regulate a bank or an insurer or what? And quite a lot of central bankers will say, or supervisors will say that the tripwire is when they start taking deposits. And--and for that reason, a lot of them have--have steered clear of anything that could look like a deposit taking activity. But if individuals are putting their money into Facebook and being given Facebook coins, as a result, that starts to look a bit like a deposit.

KIM: Although it could too, I mean, what we've seen historically, not--is that, you know, it could just be money transmitters, too if they're not actually taking a deposit but offering a--a receiving to transmit on to another location. Now you see companies like Microsoft and others that have already received their licenses to be money transferred, a financial institution, but just a--a different than deposit taking financial institution. So there could be--it'll be interesting to see how that plays out in this scenario.

CARR: It's got a lot, perhaps, about the--the timing of the transactions and--and you know, whether or not consumers are being encouraged to, you know, deposit for some put--deposit, invest a--a chunk of money for some period for these tokens that they can then redeem in due course, and whether they're incentivize by coupons or discounts or somewhere else that--that starts to look a little bit like interest, or whether it's that you're just buying the tokens each time that you need them for the--the transaction, which would look more of a--a money transfer (INAUDIBLE).

KIM: Well, yeah, it will be interesting to see how it plays out because it could also be prepaid access. If you, you know, put $100 in and then you can use that--

CARR: --Yeah--

KIM: --use on the platform.

CARR: Yeah.

KIM: It will be interesting (INAUDIBLE).

CARR: Maybe we'll find out on June 18 or--or maybe it'll be quite a long time after that.

BRUMMER: Well, I know that Amy has actually taken a keen interest in the upcoming G20 conversations, not just, you know, the--the very question of--of money transmission has to do in part, and it depends on which state you're talking about. Money transmitter laws are--are largely state-based in the United States and they have to deal with some safety and soundness issues with individual money transmitters, and you have to sort of get a license and the like. When you get to the federal level, where you're not necessarily asking about money transmission, per se, but you're concerned about market integrity, money laundering, and the other issues that are sort of embedded in the flow of money, those kinds of issues start to take on an international dimension as well. And--and Amy, I know you've been very, very involved in thinking through some of the money laundering issues, and some of the approaches taken by international regulatory authorities.

We'll be having a conversation, obviously, about the European approach and--and differences between EU and--and U.S. regulators a bit later. But there does seem to be more coordination, or at least it's--it's higher on the--on the to-do-list is--is the--is the money laundering AML question.

Where--where is--what is the state of things? What do you predict in terms of new rules and new approaches coming out from the G20?

KIM: Yeah. Well, I mean, just to start to kind of for context, I mean, certainly, you know, Bitcoin being the first iteration of blockchain that we've seen. It was a peer-to-peer payment system that's triggered financial services concerns, so that's--and--and financial services regulatory concerns, whether it's a JP Morgan coin or securities laws or, you know, anti-money laundering. That's why we've seen a lot of headwinds, I think, in the financial services space and how do they apply?

The U.S. was a--a front runner, I think, in--in addressing that in 2013, with Treasury issuing their guidance, which determined that the exchangers and administrators in this space were money transmitters, and therefore, money's a type of financial institution, the money services business in the U.S. So then that's the U.S. Federal perspective and then what you're referencing is the FATF, the Financial Action Task Force is an inner governmental body, that puts out recommendations with respect to anti-money laundering that about 200 countries then, you know, trickle down and implement in their host country.

So what they're looking at now is, you know, in October, they created a concept called Virtual Assets, which is, I think, maybe the first time I've ever seen it called Virtual Assets by a government or governmental type body, and then applied the--certain of the AML recommendations that they make to what they're calling virtual assets service providers. So that raises a couple of questions. I mean, first of all, I'm sure we all know, virtual assets can actually be a pretty broad category. These aren't all financial instruments and--

BRUMMER: --They're not all cryptocurrencies, necessarily.

KIM: Right. I mean, typically, like we've seen in the U.S., you've dealt with it as a--a--a substitute for funds or currency, you know, more like a substitute for money. Their definition goes a little bit beyond that, and it says, you know, use for payment or investment. And, you know, as we're seeing in the securities dynamic, what's--an investment can be blurred, or you could--some people can view it as an investment and some people could be using it as on a platform, which I think is a whole other thing we can all debate about, maybe at a another time.

But and so, so that kind of argument is going on, where does that fit? And there's one in particular that's going on right now, that's a bit of a hot topic for some, which is how to apply this with respect to a very specific wire transfer rule, which applies for transfers between financial institutions of $3,000 or more? In that case, you would have to obtain certain information about both the person originating the payment and the person receiving it. And so if you think about that in a blockchain context, what do you know about the person originating that and then what do you know about the person receiving it? And so that's where some of the consternation comes in and where regulators are looking for solutions.

BRUMMER: And there's been an interesting amount of back and forth and--and some contestation between industry and regulators on AML issues. I mean, the idea, obviously, is if you increasingly, not just pseudonymous, but increasingly anonymous-like transactions then that could-some be a gateway for everything from narco-trafficking, to terrorism finance, and--and other kinds of issues. And I've--I've heard as--as others probably have as--as well, that part of that Financial Action Task Force approach, which was originally sort of half of a paragraph has now sort of ballooned into sort of a multi-page analysis of--of trying to interpret an initial approach towards AML rules for--for virtual currencies. What--what exactly, to your understanding, is that point of friction between industry and the regulators on--on AML issues?

KIM: Yeah. I mean, I think one of the issues is how do you know where that money is going? You know, I think from a regulatory perspective, the--the very specific issue is about money or wire transfers, but I think the bigger issue, and those of you working traditional financial institutions, you need to know who your counter-parties are to a transaction. And so that's what traditional regulators are used to seeing. And then, so if you're looking at this and being told, "Well, I don't know who's receiving the money," you know, that's where you kind of get that. And so those are some--that's where the rub is occurring. And--and yeah.

CARR: And the industry is gun shy about that, given the magnitude of fines that have occurred in the last few years that have been specifically related to--to not having sufficient KYC, not knowing your client, not knowing where the money's going.

But also that, you know, I think the irony here is, (INAUDIBLE) the G20 have started out from this perspective I've been concerned about. I've--I've concerned about cryptocurrencies being used for AML purposes. The irony is, they're going to come around, I think, to a view that the blockchain technology is actually central to a big part of the AML fix. And I think a lot of where we're headed in the next five years is going to be around developments in digital identity, where I think blockchain has a big role.

Just to give you a couple of figures. So the UK banks spend more on AML then the UK government spends on prisons. You know, there's enormous amount of money being put by--by every bank in the world into AML systems at the moment. And the catch rate is terrible. According to Interpol, we capture between 1 and 2 percent of the illicit activity. So it's--it's a terrible return on investment for the level of--of time and money that goes in to--to AML processes at the moment. So we have to get better and smarter at it and one part of it is digital identity solutions. And I think there's other commercial imperatives for--for digital identity besides AML. So I think that this is going to have some real momentum behind it.

But again, you know, you also look at things like the feeds on a white paper that found that turning on machine learning algorithms drove a--a 75 percent catch right on fraud. The difference being that in fraud, you've got a really good reference data set to work with and in AML it's scattered all over the place. And the banks have got restrictions that mean they can't even share information within their own firm across borders on AML threats. They can't share themselves on a firm-to-firm basis. They don't get a feedback loop from law enforcement so when they fill in these thousands of suspicious transaction reports that never find out which one of those went anywhere. So you don't have the depth of the reference data to train an algorithm to get better at AML. So I--I think you're going to see that--that for, you know, given that that magnitude of that problem and the desire to get better, digital identity with blockchain having a role within it is--is a big part of what we'll see in the next five years.

KIM: I would agree with you. I feel like, sorry, that this builds into a bigger question. You know, we're--this the G20 and the FATF recommendations really focused on this one little thing on wire transfers. But that's only a very specific type of transfer between financial institutions that is triggered at a threshold level. There's all these other things that companies are doing with respect to on-boarding customers, monitoring transactions, filing transactions reports, with law enforcement responding to subpoenas, holding accounts open so law enforcement can-- You know, I mean, there's a lot that goes on in an AML compliance program. And there's--there's many people that agree. I--I'm one of them that agree that I think we need to modernize how we look at AML--

CARR: --Yep, definitely--

KIM: --compliance and enforcement. And you know, things like your name, date of birth, address, and social security number in the U.S., I mean, I don't know, does anybody here think that that's private anymore?

BRUMMER: Well, that actually is a very good question, because we are going to our Q&A for just one or two questions. We're on a very tight diplomatic schedule, not withstanding our drinks at the outset. And if there were any individuals with one or two questions, do feel free to--to ask our panelists. I do find it fascinating that, and we'll have a chance later to talk a little bit more, the one question that--that no one's really brought up is the question that is something a security or not? And even where you have a stable coin, there are certain kinds of questions that arise depending on how you stabilize a cryptocurrency and--and--and what are the methodologies and technologies and tactics used to--to stabilize and to maintain a certain price of--of crypto-asset and that becomes very important. It could even become important for Facebook and other companies.

I see, sir.

UNKNOWN: Is that when you announced (INAUDIBLE)?

BRUMMER: Exactly. And I have a solution.

QUESTION: Bert Delia (SP), banking consultant here in town.

Going back to JPM Coin, one of the objections of JPM Coin is other banks won't want to deal with it. And there's a parallel on this. Years ago, when Bank of America launched its credit card there were other--other banks that were reluctant to facilitate Bank of America Card transactions, which is why Bank of America Card eventually got spun off from B of A. So question number one is, how is JPM going to deal with that? And question number two is where does Swift fit into this picture, given the massive role that they currently play in cross-border currency movement?

SWANSON: I'll take the JPM one. So I--I don't think that their goal is to be used by everybody at this stage. They're more than happy, from my conversations, to--to work within the customer base and counter-parties and build on and see--see if there is anyone. But to your point, yeah, why--why don't other commercial banks do this? Ideally, I guess if we look at a spectrum, it would be great to have a central bank issue with digital currency. I mean, we could talk about that. Happy to discuss some of--some of the other just conversations on the sinkhole of money flour, which the BIS talked about.

To--to your point there, Brad, there's several different models on--on how central banks could do that. But yeah, a JPM point isn't trying to be everything for everybody and including for all their commercial banks.

BRUMMER: Yeah, Swift, Brad, is that something you want to--

CARR: Look, probably. I'll probably just add to that, that, you know, I think any, you know, bank issued coin is going to have a need for interoperability. And you don't want to have things fragmenting into a scenario where you have a, you know, a--a--a seller telling its buyers, "I don't want to be paid in JP Morgan Coin. I want to be paid in HSBC Coin or City Coin or whatever," then you're just fragmenting the whole system. So I think everyone's got an interest in ensuring that we get past that and we have an interoperable approach.

Swift, look, you know, I think there's--you know, and you constantly see the debate in the press with Swift and the discussions they've had with the Ripple, I think, during the Cyborgs Conference that Swift ran last year. There was a running commentary of all the--the crypto evangelists posting things furiously on every social media channel bashing Swift at the time.

My own perception is that--that the blockchain technology, where it's at right at the moment, struggles to handle the volume of transactions to be able to completely, you know, replace the existing Swift infrastructure. Where I think blockchain is really good is when you've got a smaller volume of complex transactions, trade finance, corporate lines, syndicated lines, bond insurance. So, you know, that's my sense of where the--the use cases or where it's the--the best fit. But I realize I'm wading into an area where some people hold very, very passionate views so I'm sure there's some contrarians.

BRUMMER: Well, just to piggyback on this. And I'm--I'm just curious. So if you're talking about Facebook, right, and you already have WhatsApp, so you--you kind of have a messaging system, right. So--so the question is, how do you then, you know, if you think of the--the sort of life-cycle of the transaction, of the messaging, and then you have the settlement. And the question is, you know, how do you scale up to be able to handle lots of different--different transactions? And I guess you could say the same even if you had a large retailer, you know, like Amazon, creating a--a--they came out with a--a Bezos coin or something, you could--you could figure out some-- Or the--they--they already have an internal messaging protocol system. It's going to be the--it's going to be how do you actually use the--the--the blockchain technology.

I think you can make a point that having a better balance between the banking system and the non-banking system is that you can make the financial system more stable. And you will understand that in these discussions, the U.S. is frequently mentioned as, you know, the example where you have much more successful--well, capital markets are much deeper and--and they play a bigger role in the--in the economy and the financial system. We should--we should do the--you know, we--we should push for that, where Europe has been working on it for--for many decades already. And so I'm sure that the next European Commission will, again, work on that.

I think where technology comes in is where--one area where we think there needs to be much more improvements, is around cheaper distribution of products to retail consumers, you know, more standardization, more robo advice, more transparency on costs. We would hope that technology helps there to make sure that we get a better deal for--for the end consumer.

Currently, as a consumer, we can see that in our day to day lives is that there's been the biggest progress, at least how I see it, is--is in the payments area, our banking apps, how we can do the payments so much easier in our family, how we can now get better deals in terms of when we are in--in the U.S. and having a better rate for exchanging the U.S. dollar against the euro. And so in the payments area, we--I--you can see, and I'm personally I experienced as a client, how much progress there has been there. I can really see that there's been so much benefit to the consumer. I think that is not as far yet in securities markets. But there I would hope that in terms of standardization of advice, making it more inclusive advice, which is available for also people with a smaller purse, and more transparency of financial products, that they're--especially technology can help.

Other areas, there is where, of course, we're working on is--is things like cloud issues. Supervisory issues are very important for us. Cybersecurity risks are important for us. We're working on that.

BRUMMER: And that would be at the Capital Markets Union level?

MAIJOOR: Well, on the--I think on the capital markets unions, especially I--I think the distribution, cheaper distribution, more transparent distribution, I would--you know, we have seen in so many parts of our lives how services have improved because of technology. Securities markets have been lagging a--a bit there. And--and I think it--it will be--that is the area where I see the opportunity.

BRUMMER: Fascinating.

Are there any questions from our audience? This reminds me of my law school course.

(LAUGHTER)

Afraid of the regulator to--to raise your hand.

MAIJOOR: There's one.

BRUMMER: All right, excellent.

MAIJOOR: He--he saves it.

BRUMMER: He does save it.

MAIJOOR: He's there.

QUESTION. Hi. My name is President Sibbett. I'm a--a postdoctoral fellow at the Global Governance Center, at the Graduate Student Union in Switzerland.

I'm just wondering what thought ESMA has given in terms of developing regulations to assert European strategic autonomy in relations to U.S. sanctions, and particularly, as it relates to the--in the area of cryptocurrencies and what can be created there? Thank you.

MAIJOOR: Sorry, on which area?

QUESTION: Strategic autonomy from U.S. sanctions and U.S. regulations.

MAIJOOR: Well, I--I think probably I would not be--you know, this is--this is not the, let's say, the typical area of the--of a securities markets regulator. And so I'm--I'm getting into territory where I do it more, basically, as a--as a reader of newspapers than with the expertise knowledge. But we--we know, but just to convey that message, we know that there are discussions around-- You know, one of the implications of sanctions and effectiveness also is very much related to the role of the currency that it plays in global trade. And we--we very much know that the U.S. dollar has been much more successful in that respect than the euro.

I think, what is interesting there, I think the--so far the formal position has been, from most of the central bankers that I know, is that they are say, you know, whether--whether the euro would be a, let's say, a global currency that is used trade, if we are neutral visa vi that position, you can see, at least I've seen some signals, that you can see that that is changing by some of the central banking and some in the central bank community.

BRUMMER: And certainly, when it comes to the AML issues, one thing I noticed, just reading the--the earlier consultative reports, is that from ESMA and--and from the EBA, is that there does seem, and it's not the same thing as sanctions, but on the AML and a conversation that we had just in the preceding panel, that there does seem to be a lot of energy and--and--and work towards pushing through a very unified approach, and an upgraded approach towards any AML related issues, both in your Europe and--and globally.

MAIJOOR: Just to, because I--just to--one other part of the coin, I know that there's been and I--maybe that's the--the--the other part of your--your question, so we know that there's been sanctions in certain--certain countries, you know, outside of the--outside of the EU. If you're talking about sanctions by, let's say, regulators from the U.S. visa vi European finance or market participants, in principle, I think that is part of a system where you, without going into individual cases and whether they are right or wrong in individual cases, but I think the consequence of global capital markets, where you have supervision at a--at a national or regional level is, and if there would be a foreign market participant active in the EU and they will do--you know, they would not live by the EU rules, I think it is--it is right to be sanctions in--in that case.

And so maybe that is the other part of your question or the issue you're referring to. But in principle, I think that is a--a possibility that is related to the fact that you have global capital markets, that if you provide services cross border, there are--is there is indeed, the possibility that if--if those services are provided cross border, but they don't meet the--the--the relevant rules and regulations in that country, is that you can be sanctioned.

BRUMMER: Given the cross border, and I--this is a way to maybe, perhaps, tie up the earlier panel with--with this one, from ESMA's perspective, when you hear about companies like Facebook, or JP Morgan and other companies, big tech, entering into the space, do you have any--any thoughts, observations? Does--does this percolate to the--to--to your--to your to-do-list when you see these companies themselves thinking about creating alternative, or--or I shouldn't say alternative, but creating virtual currencies that, obviously, are going to be, in--in the case of Facebook, potentially used all over the world and--and--and within the European Union?

MAIJOOR: Well, obviously, as far as, you know, what--what I my understanding, so far, this is more in--in--and you call it also currency and so it would be more for the banking regulators to work on that. But obviously, on ICOs, on crypto-assets with an investment, a characteristic on these things we talk, you know, we talked globally, we talk to each other. We, in (INAUDIBLE) we inform each other about our experiences. This is an area where, as a regulator, you need to be humble, you need to be--you try to understand these new developments. And so there is a global regulatory community thinking about these issues. We know that the FSB is involved into analyzing crypto-assets and--and I think that--is that is only logical. Typically, these new developments, you need all the brainpower and--and the--the expertise to address those issues. And so, you know, obviously, talking about these issues on a--on a global basis among regulators is very important.

BRUMMER: And with the public.

Thank you so very much for your time. It's been immensely useful for the Washington community.

(APPLAUSE)

MAIJOOR: Thank you very much.

BRUMMER: Thank you, sir.

MAIJOOR: Thank you.

BRUMMER: Thank you. Appreciate it.

RESNIK: All right. Thank you, Chris and Mr. Maijoor, for the fascinating discussion, and a special thank you to Georgetown University Law Center for hosting us this evening.

Two things to leave you with. First, a quick reminder to subscribe to Chris's FinTech Beat podcast, now available on iTunes and in fact, tonight's interview with Mr. Maijoor will be the next episode. And second, the bar is still open--

(LAUGHTER)

--so feel free to enjoy. That concludes our programming for tonight. Thank you so much for coming and we look forward to seeing you at our next event.

(APPLAUSE)

Cq Roll Call, Institute For International Economic Law And Institute For Financial Markets Holds Forum On Blockchain Infrastructures

October 23, 2019 09:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

GEORGETOWN CENTER FOR FINANCIAL MARKETS AND POLICY DIRECTOR REENA AGGARWAAL

FISCALNOTE CONTENT OPERATIONS VICE PRESIDENT MIKE NOLAN

[*]NOLAN: --for financial markets this morning for the third day of D.C. FinTech. My name is Mike Nolan and I am the vice president of content at CQ Roll Call. And I just want to say, I'm thankful for everyone here joining us this morning as well as those liveing--watching on our livestream.

Today's discussion will spotlight the blockchain infrastructures, regulatory responses to Facebook's Libra, Wall Street's perspective and the future of cryptocurrency regulation. As we all, know Mark Zuckerberg will be speaking in front of Congress this morning and we want to make sure to keep you ahead of the curve on what's going on. So we will be simulcasting the latest news updates from our hearings, from our journalists down on Capitol Hill and we will be directing questions to our panelists to get their reactions, fact checks and observations.

But before we kick off the discussion, I like just to set the stage for today's dialogue. As you know, we--today's world is a rapidly changing one and every industry is going through some transformation and turbulence, mainly driven by technology but also political and governmental changes as well. And at CQ Roll Call, for the last 75 years, our publications have been unbend the--unbiased nonpartisan legislative and regulatory analysis.

And now, in partnership with Chris Brummer, we've launched a--launch new coverage of FinTech's technological and regulatory impacts. Our latest podcast which I recommend subscribing is Fintech Beat which features exclusive interviews with U.S. and global thought leaders to help listeners stay informed of cutting-edge issues and inno--innovation is transforming the business of money.

(AUDIO GAP)

AGGARWAAL: Good morning and welcome. As Mark mentioned, I'm Reena Aggarwaal, the director of the Georgetown Center for Financial Markets and Policy. We at Georgetown are delighted to be part of this event and we really are doing a lot of work. Chris Brummer and his team at the Law Center, at the business school, at other parts of Georgetown, we are doing a lot of work on FinTech, blockchain. And we have a number of partners like we are part of the Ripple university ini--initiative. And so we are delighted to have you here today.

And I have the pleasure of having an amazing group of panelists here. One of our panel members is stuck in Washington traffic and will join us very soon. It's a fascinating time to be in D.C. with everything that's going on here, but I'm talking about the Nats, right, and so we're--we're thrilled to have the Nats in the World Series. But le--let's talk about our panel here. We're going to look at the macro view and before we get started, I'm going to ask our panelists to introduce themselves and tell us a little bit about what they do and then, we'll go right into the questions.

CARTER: Okay, Thank you, Reena and thank you to Chris for inviting me back for another year. It's a great pleasure to be here. So my name is Nic Carter, I'm a partner at a venture firm called Castle Island Ventures based in Boston. We invest in start-ups building on top or adjacent to public blockchains exclusively and I'm also the founder of a start-up called Coin Metrics, which is a start-up that pulls economic data out of block chains to trying to understand them and to characterize the nature of the blockchain economy.

BENCH: Thank you, Reena. I'm Bob Bench. I am the director of Applied Fintech Research at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. As a Bostonian, I am terribly disappointed to see this many people in the room. After game one in 2004, when the Red Sox played, we would not be awake at this point. I think we would still be celebrating. I'm a neighbor of Nic in Cambridge as well.

The applied Fintech Research Division is part of a system effort to effectively better understand emerging technologies and--and how we can use those emerging technologies to better the goals of the system. And to that point, we provide subject matter assistance. One thing I'm learning at the Federal Reserve, I'm brand-new, is that to call yourself an expert at the Federal Reserve means you probably need 20 to 40 years in any specific subject matter.

I am far too green to ever consider myself an expert within that system. And then, we do real experimentation with real technology to understand what tools we can use to improve our methods of managing and overseeing firms in the economy as a whole.

DARROW: Good morning. My name is Ian Darrow, I work for a company called Protocol Labs which is a company to build open source software to upgrade the fundamental infrastructure of the Internet. One of our projects is a public cryptocurrency that is attempting to create a decentralized market for file storage. I'm based here in D.C., I wear two hats of Protocol Labs. One is senior policy counsel and one is software engineer.

So my theory is that to make staying policy around this stuff, you should understand how it works at a pretty detailed level. That's what I try to do, although, we'll see.

AGGARWAAL: Okay. So but let's kick off into our macro topic for the panel here. And we have a number of central banks from China, Sweden, Bahamas and lots of other countries that have started to experiment with the whole idea of digital currencies. And--and then we have other central banks that are taking a much more cautious approach to this. So just a broad question. Do you think it's inevitable that central banks will have these digital currencies that will play a global role? Anyone.

CARTER: So I--I would say, I always find the phrase CBDC kind of funny because most currency is already digital. You know, we have cash obviously, but it's being--it's being increasingly marginalized. As--as--as governments try and enhance their surveillance over the economy and in--in places like Sweden, cash is--is almost obsolete.

So it seems like it's an inevitability that governments will try and exert more and more control over their citizens through the lens of--of money and--and you know, privacy in terms of transactions will be a thing of the past, whether it happens through a CBDC, I can't speak to that, I don't know. But it certainly seems to be the direction things are heading.

BENCH: Yeah, I think, I mean, as a central banker, I guess I need to answer this one. To your point, most value in the world is already a CBDC, right? So commercial banks have exclusive rights to the central bank and all, right. Retail persons don't have access to CBDC. I think that's a differentiation. People talk about CBDC., what they're really talking about is retail, CBDC. direct--direct to non-banks--non-commercial banks.

And inevitably, I think technology's inevitable but how it gets pushed out in a policy way is--is a very broad question. But I think part of our job in Boston is to be what we call curious but careful, right? We want to understand the developments and we will not--there's no head-in-the-sand going on with our division. By careful meeting, this is the most critical infrastructure in the United States from an economic standpoint, and so--and there's a lot of smart people that have built the, you know, the digitalization of value within the Federal Reserve System who have been doing it for 20 and 30 and 40 years.

So this isn't their first rodeo at digitalizing value, and so we're understanding what other countries are doing but we're careful because we understand how critical it is from my infrastructure standpoint.

DARROW: We're unanimous that currency is already digital. So the panel agrees which I think is good. I would strongly echo Bob's point that this is a question not of whether digital currencies will become prominent but of who will get to access and control them. It's totally critical infrastructure, there's a real value judgment there in terms of whether you think that access that infrastructure should be pushed all the way down the stack to individual users or whether it's important to have it controlled and monitored by a smaller and, you know, arguably or more trusted or not, group of people depending on which governments in which countries you're talking about and I think that's one of the fundamental questions in this space right now.

AGGARWAAL: So if it's inevitable and it's going to happen, it's already happening and our panelists are unanimous about that. What are the concerns of some central banks are being a lot more cautious while others are being more aggressive about it, what are the concerns? What are the pitfalls to watch out for?

DARROW: Here's a concern that I've heard articulated on the Hill in meetings which is that the American financial system--I'm talking--I'm talking about the United States specifically, although obviously other countries working on this as well. The concern is that the American financial system is the envy of the world and it's because our markets are so orderly and so regulated. So we should be conservative in our approach, we should sort of let this innovation happen somewhere else then see how it goes and then take the best pieces and incorporate them into our system, and then capital will flow back into the American system once it implements this infrastructure.

I've heard this argument made, I think it's 180 degrees wrong. I think technology moves really quickly and when it takes hold someplace sometimes, that's permanent. So like for example, Silicon Valley is Silicon Valley because Fairchild Semiconductor was there for like a five year period and tons of smart people acquired a bunch of capital because it was really important and now, 50 years later that's still the center of tech in the developed world. So the same thing could happen in the financial system if cryptocurrency or digital currencies are really important innovation and they get built somewhere else.

AGGARWAAL: So I get it that the U.S. financial system it's huge it's really large it's complex and so the regulators want to be careful. But then at the same time, I wonder about this China, it's--it's pretty huge and certainly in terms of number of people it's complex but they seem to be more aggressive about it.

CARTER: It's because they have less of a concern for individual rights to be perfectly frank about it. So the fact that all commerce in China is surveyed through WeChat and Alipay, that's acceptable under their standard. But--and I don't think it would be acceptable to many individuals in the U.S. who value things like transactional privacy. You know, we're increasingly seeing financial exclusion being used as a--as a cudgel to, you know, de-platform entities which are deemed problematic, you know, whether that's, you know, corporations that sell guns.

For instance, so it's, you know, the banks are being pressured to stop that flavor of commerce or social media platforms which don't adhere to the conventional standard in terms of suppressing speech or, you know, sex workers who--who get kicked off of Venmo or PayPal. So, you know, in the U.S. , we're seeing an erosion as well and, you know, probably approaching the Chinese standard but many people hold these values very dear and if we--we totally surrender our financial rails to, you know, either the government or corporations and we lose the--the anonymity characteristics of cash I think that has a really chilling effect potentially.

I know lots of people in this room would disagree with that but I--I think that's a value that--that many people hold dear and--and is coming under pressure as we--we--we start to surrender transactions to either corporate or governmental monopolies.

AGGARWAAL: So is that why we get so concerned when the private sector or big tech, Facebook for example, gets into this business, the privacy issues, the data issues in addition to who lost, a lot of other issues, is that sort of why the concern is if the central bank is doing it it's different?

CARTER: Well I mean, soon Zuckerberg will testify today and I'm sure he'll be challenged on the fact that, you know Facebook, effectively is an algorithmic censor of speech and, you know, they do--they decide which narratives to promote, which to suppress and, you know, why wouldn't they pursue that with Libra as well? I mean, I would be--I think I'd be surprised if Zuckerberg isn't challenged on that front today.

We trade a whole lot of scalability for trust. we get trust by having massive decentralization. Many, many computer nodes kept in sync by a consensus algorithm. All consensus algorithms everywhere and there are lots of different examples of these historically, elect a leader in some way and they have everybody else follow in behind the leader. A very energy consumptive and efficient way of electing a leader is by making all of the different computers solve a complex puzzle. And so, Bitcoin invented a decentralized way of electing a leader. And, can have the first really decentralized way in history.

And, unfortunately, it has become a very inefficient system. It burns an enormous amount of energy and wastes a lot of computation, requires specialized hardware. Way more security cost than is necessary. Proof of stake replaces all of that waste with a cryptoeconomic bond basically. So, if I have a bunch of Ether, I can stake it in a smart connect in a program on the blockchain and that gives me the right to validate transactions and blocks on this network.

If I behave badly, the software can come along and take away my security bond, essentially. It's more decentralized because the barrier to entry to participating is very low compared to proof of work. And, the efficiencies of scale don't exist. So, if I'm running a Chinese warehouse behind the great firewall, I have tremendous efficiencies of scale there. Messages moving across the firewall are disadvantaged. And I think from an investor standpoint, we're seeing this movement into, you know, really focusing on these disrupting type of models, but also the second question that comes up was what's the--what are the risks? And what is, you know, execution risk obviously, you know, there's--where is this ton of benefits because of, you know, the different delivery of financial services and the demographic change with the younger people and Millennials thinking about financial services in a whole different way. But, on the flip side, can we get to market, especially with this whole arc of regulatory uncertainty. How does that fit into it? and so, you know, having these discussions is really, back to my earlier comments at the front end, you know, during an investment process or a funding round and understanding how are you gonna deal with this--these risks are important in terms of determining whether this is viable--viable thing to move on.

BUCHANAN: You're up next.

TUTEJA: Yeah, I think I'll double click on what I've kind of shared. I think I've always believed education is the silver bullet. You know, personally and professionally, I mean, it's been a cornerstone for everything we've done for over 40 years as TD Ameritrade part of given the ethos of our business, but secondly, it's, you know, whether you're investing in a startup as a credit investor, whether you're investing in traditional markets and all the (INAUDIBLE), whether you're investing in digital assets, I think at the end of the day, you know, you have to make sure that you're learning about it, right? And, you know, when it comes to digital assets, of course, when you work in this field and everybody has an opinion and they want to share it with you. I was joking when my announcement became public that I was taking on this role, 50 percent of the emails I got were congratulatory and 50 percent were condolences.

(LAUGHTER)

But, you know, and everyone's got an opinion and that's cool. But the line I always tell people was it could be (INAUDIBLE), I don't really believe in it and then they'll apologize. I'm like it's okay to be skeptical. But, it's not okay to be ignorant, right? And, I mean, I remember getting into this space in late 2011, early 2012 and I compare that to today, where the number of resources for you to self-learn were so different than today. Today, there's a proliferation of experts who are on podcasts on YouTube channel. I know a lot of these sessions are being live streamed. Like, you know, there's so much credible reading material. And, yes, sometimes it's drama filled. Crypto Twitter can be. It's also very informative. And I always tell people you make up your mind. It's up to you.

You know, and also I think the cool thing with crypto is, it's very multidisciplinary. Everybody comes into it for their own different ethos and reasons. You know, Wall Street, has a different opinion, technologists have a different opinion. I think that diversity of thought is--I mean, I was on a fork last year where I was deciding of what I should do my PhD, I was gonna either go the AI route or the crypto route. One of the reasons I chose the crypto route was I actually found the crypto community much, much more inclusive and accepting of all different varieties of ethos and diversity. So, you know, I'll end my (INAUDIBLE) with saying there's a lot of information at your fingertips. And, again, kudos to Chris and his team for putting this together. Just scan the book of folks who've attended here today or spoken at, follow them on Twitter. Start with that. And just, you know, invest in your crypto quotient and then make your own decisions.

ADAMJEE: Yeah, that's great. Chris?

WHITE: Look, I think the most valuable thing from this entire exercise in innovation is just changing the rules around access to capital. When you change the rules around access to capital that's when we've seen major shifts in world history. Napoleon changed the rules around access to capital and was able to mobilize the biggest army that Europe had ever seen. Prior to that, financing an army was totally different. And we--what we--what's possible is being able to give more people access to actual capital and instead of having to depend on the traditional banking system.

What I would most like to see is the actual central banking system think about using blockchain and all of this fabulous technology as a part of the way they control the money supply because we have a banking system that's almost 100 years old that literally is using the same workflow of ease the access to capital for the major events and somehow it will get to the individuals.

UNKNOWN: Yeah.

WHITE: And that has been abused for quite a long time. And so, I'm hopeful that maybe in certain areas of the world central banks can start setting an example where if you want to help the economy in your country start to use crypto and DLT to actually get the money to the people who are actually can start small businesses and hire people instead of just creating a cycle in which like what we've seen in the United States where certain banks can borrow zero and then invest in interest bearing instruments that have no risk. And the taxpayer pays for that. So, that's what I would really like to see from this. I think that's a big change to the way the world works.

There are other things that are nice, but that's what I think is the most valuable?

ADAMJEE: Matt?

HOMER: Yeah, I mean I would--and just picking up on that. So, I'm a big believer that as a supervisor, as a regulator, you can only effectively regulate and supervise these markets when you use some of this technology yourself. And when you--when you kind of really rustle with it and use it in your day to day life and work responsibilities. So, I think from a DFS perspective, I mean, yes, kind of what we'll be investing in. I mean I think that that will be a focus going forward is how do we improve our own technology. How do we use the type of technology that people are talking about here to do our jobs more effectively?

The other thing I'd say very--you know, very self servantly, is that I'm--you know, I think we'll also be investing in talent and trying to hire people to like, you know, grow our team. I think that it's a very exciting time to be a regulator around this issue. You know, it's a nascent space and we're kind of building the regulatory framework as the market evolves. So, I think it's an exciting time to be a part of that.

ADAMJEE: Great. Do you have any other questions? I think we probably just have time for one. Yeah?

QUESTION: I just had a comment.

ADAMJEE: Yeah.

QUESTION: Mike Chan (PH), NWC Consulting (PH), the comment about 3 million Bitcoins left to be mined and what are thoughts on that. I think the monetary policy of bit coin (INAUDIBLE) millions of dollars (INAUDIBLE) is one of the most compelling things about Bitcoin making it deflationary. But I think that when miners--at the end when there's very few bit coins left to mine, then the compensated mostly in transaction fees instead of actual bit coin can be a problem with their--with their incentives to continue to maintain the security of the bit coin network. So, just a comment. I know there's a lot of different views about that. So, I would love to just have a--

TUTEJA: --We can debate over cocktails.

ADAMJEE: Let's continue that conversation upstairs. No, all right, that's a wrap. Okay. Thanks.

urn:contentItem:5WN6-3XD1-JD34-V4M0-00000-00Crackdown looms for tech giants;Digital Inquiry2019-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Crackdown looms for tech giantsDigital InquiryFergus Hunter and Jennifer Duke

The government will seize on a landmark inquiry to promise sweeping changes to some of the world's most recognised digital giants in an intervention that threatens to disrupt the business models of powerful internet platforms.

The final report of the ACCC's digital platforms inquiry will be released today and is expected to focus in on the domination of Facebook and Google, demanding greater scrutiny of their operations and market power.

The tightly held report was handed to the government at the end of June. Traditional media outlets are expecting a suite of measures that will level the playing field and allow them to better monetise their content

The digital players fear the government will pursue intrusive and "unworkable" regulation over the algorithms behind their platforms. They are concerned that global regulators and authorities will be inspired by Australia's measures.

A source close to Treasurer Josh Frydenberg said the minister viewed the tech giants as an "existential" threat to media companies.

While Mr Frydenberg will embrace the report's findings, the government is expected to take time to detail its full response. The wide-ranging implications and complexity of the ACCC report's contents may require extensive consultation.

Tough measures on competition and privacy would open up a new front in the government's fight with the tech sector, which Prime Minister Scott Morrison has already taken to task over its role in the dissemination of violent and extremist material online.

Labor MP Ed Husic said the global industry would be preparing for the report given its potential implications. "Big tech knows that a lot of regulators have taken a great interest in this and will be wondering if the tremors flying out of the pages of this report will be felt elsewhere," he said.

"The sector should be rightly worried because they have snubbed their noses at calls to deal with these issues and now it's time for competition law to deal with their failure to act."

Accepting that sweeping changes are inevitable, the tech companies are preparing to mount a concerted effort to manage the report's findings to achieve the best possible outcome for their business interests. The tech lobby has warned that many businesses would be harmed by measures designed to take on Facebook and Google. Smaller businesses and start-ups may not have the capacity to comply with sweeping new regulations.

The ACCC's preliminary report released in December recommended a range of changes including a new regulatory authority investigating algorithms and the ranking of news, an ombudsman to handle complaints and new rules requiring opt-in consent for data collection.

The additional oversight has seen existing regulators jostling for territory, with media sources believing the Australian Communications and Media Authority will be given an expanded role in managing the digital platforms. ACMA currently polices the television and radio broadcasters.

The report also suggested a further review of the regulations currently affecting traditional media companies, a news literacy program and tax-deductible news subscriptions for all Australians.

Traditional media companies have called on the competition watchdog to crack down on the market power of the tech giants, in particular Google and Facebook, to help them negotiate better rates and terms when using the businesses to share content online.

Jul 25, 2019( Fox Hounds: http://www.foxandhoundsdaily.com/Delivered by Newstex) The Federal Justice Department announced a broad antitrust review of large tech firms with three of top companies often mentioned headquartered in California. If Facebook, Google and Apple are all found to be restricting competition with monopolistic behavior, they could face disciplinary actions with one option in the extreme case, forced breakup.

California's booming economy and government revenue has come to rely heavily on the tech industry. Justice Department antitrust chief Makan Delrahim said in a statement, 'Without the discipline of meaningful market-based competition, digital platforms may act in ways that are not responsive to consumer demands.' The Justice Department review is just the first step and much has to happen before actions could take a bite out of the state's economy. But the step toward trust busting is no surprise. I've reported in the last couple of years of a growing concern over the power centered in a few tech companies. The old trust busting efforts hailed in the early 20th century could make a comeback. While undoing the monopolies over 100 years ago centered on monopolistic control of commodities, like Standard Oil's command of oil, tech controls massive amounts of data. And with their economic power, some Silicon Valley companies are moving into other industries. The trouble for the tech firms is that their popularity is on the wane. Both Democrats and Republicans have raised concerns about the big companies' dominance. In fact, in her list of policy solutions, Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren, the senator from Massachusetts, has spoken of breaking up Google, Facebook and Amazon. Now the Trump Justice Department is following a path that could lead to breakup. Investors have indicated their unhappiness with these developments. If regulations and breakup come what damage would be done to the state economy and revenue gathering? The state would feel a pinch. The potential for less pay for tech's top executives would undoubtedly be reflected in the state's income tax take. Remember that the top 1% of California income tax payers account for about half of the state's income tax revenue which is around 70% of the General Fund. A hit on the incomes of rich tech executives could be felt in the state budget. On the other hand, if a breakup leads to other or new California businesses filling the gap, newly created or increased state revenue could come from taxpayers added to the state's rolls. Further, while Apple and Google's parent company Alphabet are in the top 5 publically traded companies in California, the state's economy relies on other sectors of the economy to flourish. Finance, real estate, agriculture and manufacturing are all bulwarks of the state's economy. Still, the tech industry has been a strong sector partly responsible for the state's rise to the fifth largest economy in the world. Damage to that sector would be felt.

urn:contentItem:5WPV-MNM1-JBKR-R0N5-00000-00Crackdown on big tech rivals could be 'tremendous' opportunity for Shopify2019-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. D1 Crackdown on big tech rivals could be 'tremendous' opportunity for ShopifyJames McleodFinancial Post Jmcleod@Nationalpost.Com Twitter: Jamespmcleod

The backlash against big tech could be a huge benefit for Canada's biggest tech company.

Shopify Inc. reported strong second quarter earnings Thursday that topped analyst expectations, and improved guidance from the company management sent the stock surging.

But at least one analyst thinks that Shopify stands to benefit even further, as pressure mounts on governments to regulate some of its biggest competitors, in particular Amazon.com Inc.

"I'm of the belief that the global government scrutiny and potential for incremental regulation is a tremendous net positive for Shopify," D.A. Davidson analyst Tom Forte said in an interview with the Financial Post on Thursday.

On the company's Q2 earnings call for Thursday, Forte asked Shopify CEO Tobi Lutke about the "four horsemen of big technology" and how things could shake out if the U.S. government moves to regulate or even break up companies like Amazon, Google, Facebook and Apple.

"First of all, I think it's a very, very healthy debate for every country and society to just, you know, at least meditate on how the largest companies fit into society, and what roles they should play," Lutke said.

Shopify Inc. reported strong second quarter earnings Thursday that topped analyst expectations, and improved guidance from the company management sent the stock surging.

But at least one analyst thinks that Shopify stands to benefit even further, as pressure mounts on governments to regulate some of its biggest competitors, in particular Amazon.com Inc.

"I'm of the belief that the global government scrutiny and potential for incremental regulation is a tremendous net positive for Shopify," D.A. Davidson analyst Tom Forte said in an interview with the Financial Post on Thursday.

On the company's Q2 earnings call for Thursday, Forte asked Shopify CEO Tobi Lutke about the "four horsemen of big technology" and how things could shake out if the U.S. government moves to regulate or even break up companies like Amazon, Google, Facebook and Apple.

"First of all, I think it's a very, very healthy debate for every country and society to just, you know, at least meditate on how the largest companies fit into society, and what roles they should play," Lutke said.

"When I talk with politicians - and I do - the thing that we get to pretty quickly is that the future needs millions and millions of small businesses creating good jobs for 10 to 50 people, or maybe beyond in certain circumstances. So I do feel comfortable with how Shopify fits within this picture."

The backlash against the world's biggest technology companies, sparked by the Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal, has been building for more than a year. Last week, the U.S. Justice Department announced a broad antitrust investigation of big tech.

Forte said that there's a perception that Shopify depends on Facebook, because the platform does a lot of e-commerce social media advertising, especially on Instagram. But Forte doesn't really buy that.

"Shopify is less dependent on Facebook than many investors think," he said.

"I would argue that tomorrow the company could disassociate with Facebook, and it would have a material negative impact, but it would not have a large material negative impact."

The discussion of Shopify's role in the big tech ecosystem also came up when Lutke was asked on the earnings call about Shopify's use of data to drive value for the business.

Lutke didn't mention Amazon by name, but he specifically talked about one of Amazon's most controversial practices - creating inhouse brands to compete with the small merchants who sell on their platform.

"It's an interesting time for data.

Like, I want to be careful, because there's a really, really strong principle at this company that the data is the merchant's, and we use it to their exact benefit," he said.

"It's important to say that what Shopify won't do is sort of take the aggregate total and act on the leanings to our benefit. We see this in the history of retail a lot, large vendors go and create retail brands or in-house brands based on the insights that they are only marginally entitled to, and this is just not the right move."

Lutke said that a good example of how Shopify likes to use data is the recently announced Shopify Fulfillment Network which will handle warehousing and shipping for merchants on the platform.

"We can, based on historics of their sales (and) demand course and so on, we can predict - right now we're at about 85 per cent accuracy - from which region the next order is going to come, and where demand is going to be needed," he said.

Shopify revenue was up by 48 per cent to US$362 million, and the company posted adjusted net income of US$4.8 million for the quarter. At the same time, the company raised its guidance for the fiscal year.

Shopify stock shot up by 10 per cent when the market opened, before falling back to close the day at $451.58 up 7.67 per cent on the TSX.

According to Suthan Sukumar, analyst covering the company for Eight Capital, one thing really caused the markets to move was the guidance that the company will maintain the same level of profitability, even as they make major investments in expanding their product offering. "This is still a growth story. There's still significant runway and room for continued investment to make sure that they maintain their competitive position." urn:contentItem:5WPV-YWY1-DY2T-F534-00000-00Crackdown on big tech rivals could be 'tremendous'opportunity for Shopify2019-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. B10Crackdown on big tech rivals could be 'tremendous'opportunity for ShopifyJames McleodFinancial Post

The backlash against big tech could be a huge benefit for Canada's biggest tech company.

Shopify Inc. reported strong second quarter earnings Thursday that topped analyst expectations, and improved guidance from the company management sent the stock surging.

But at least one analyst thinks that Shopify stands to benefit even further, as pressure mounts on governments to regulate some of its biggest competitors, in particular Amazon.com Inc.

"I'm of the belief that the global government scrutiny and potential for incremental regulation is a tremendous net positive for Shopify," D.A. Davidson analyst Tom Forte said in an interview with the Financial Post on Thursday.

On the company's Q2 earnings call for Thursday, Forte asked Shopify CEO Tobi Lutke about the "four horsemen of big technology" and how things could shake out if the U.S. government moves to regulate or even break up companies like Amazon, Google, Facebook and Apple.

"First of all, I think it's a very, very healthy debate for every country and society to just, you know, at least meditate on how the largest companies fit into society, and what roles they should play," Lutke said.

"When I talk with politicians - and I do - the thing that we get to pretty quickly is that the future needs millions and millions of small businesses creating good jobs for 10 to 50 people, or maybe beyond in certain circumstances. So I do feel comfortable with how Shopify fits within this picture."

The backlash against the world's biggest technology companies, sparked by the Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal, has been building for more than a year. Last week, the U.S. Justice Department announced a broad antitrust investigation of big tech.

Forte said that there's a perception that Shopify depends on Facebook, because the platform does a lot of e-commerce social media advertising, especially on Instagram. But Forte doesn't really buy that.

"Shopify is less dependent on Facebook than many investors think," he said.

"I would argue that tomorrow the company could disassociate with Facebook, and it would have a material negative impact, but it would not have a large material negative impact."

The discussion of Shopify's role in the big tech ecosystem also came up when Lutke was asked on the earnings call about Shopify's use of data to drive value for the business.

Lutke didn't mention Amazon by name, but he specifically talked about one of Amazon's most controversial practices - creating inhouse brands to compete with the small merchants who sell on their platform.

"It's an interesting time for data.

Like, I want to be careful, because there's a really, really strong principle at this company that the data is the merchant's, and we use it to their exact benefit," he said.

"It's important to say that what Shopify won't do is sort of take the aggregate total and act on the leanings to our benefit. We see this in the history of retail a lot, large vendors go and create retail brands or in-house brands based on the insights that they are only marginally entitled to, and this is just not the right move."

Lutke said that a good example of how Shopify likes to use data is the recently announced Shopify Fulfillment Network which will handle warehousing and shipping for merchants on the platform.

"We can, based on historics of their sales (and) demand course and so on, we can predict - right now we're at about 85 per cent accuracy - from which region the next order is going to come, and where demand is going to be needed," he said.

Shopify revenue was up by 48 per cent to US$362 million, and the company posted adjusted net income of US$4.8 million for the quarter. At the same time, the company raised its guidance for the fiscal year.

Shopify stock shot up by 10 per cent when the market opened, before falling back to close the day at $451.58 up 7.67 per cent on the TSX.

According to Suthan Sukumar, analyst covering the company for Eight Capital, one thing really caused the markets to move was the guidance that the company will maintain the same level of profitability, even as they make major investments in expanding their product offering. "This is still a growth story. There's still significant runway and room for continued investment to make sure that they maintain their competitive position."
