urn:contentItem:5T4N-4GV1-JBHT-D4X5-00000-00Crash at U.K. Parliament; Funding America's Military; Trump Signs Defense Bill; London Driver Arrested on Suspicion of Terrorism; U.S.-Turkey Relations; Firefighter From Utah Dies in California Wildfires; Braves Ronald Acuna Jr. Hits Lead Off Home Run In Both Doubleheader Game; Marlins Coach Keeps Wet Lettuce Under His Helmet To Stay Cool2018-08-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisCrash at U.K. Parliament; FundingAmerica's Military; Trump Signs Defense Bill; London Driver Arrested on Suspicion of Terrorism; U.S.-Turkey Relations; Firefighter FromUtah Dies in California Wildfires; Braves Ronald Acuna Jr. Hits Lead Off Home Run In Both Doubleheader Game; Marlins Coach Keeps Wet Lettuce Under His Helmet To Stay CoolLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: All right. An thank you for joining us. We're going to say good morning to --

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Neil Cavuto.

SIMONETTI: -- Cavuto. Whoa.

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It is very early. It's very, very early. But I admire how you guys do that. All right. Thank you very much guys. We are following on a couple of developments here. I'm very happy to have you.

I am Neil Cavuto in for my colleague and friend Maria Bartiromo. We're going to be getting a very big news coming on the retail sector. Home Depot kicking things off, we'll get to that in a second. I should also tell you that things have stabilized when it comes to Turkey.

Now, that's sort of a perspective on just the freefall had stopped. That doesn't take away the fact that the currency has been cut in half if you think about it in a little more than a couple of weeks. So we'll be on top of that and the fallout.

But for the Futures, for the European markets, with the Asian markets they've welcomed these developments because the beating has for the moment stopped. That doesn't mean that the beating will not resume down the road. For now, the markets are seizing on this as a promising development.

We should also say that these contagion fears are still real no matter what is happening. We're following on that, the effects it could have on markets that sparked on in South Africa, in Argentina, Brazil, you name it, they're all caught in the mix,.

Here with me today, Fox Contributor Kat Timpf. We've got the Wall Street Journal Global Economics Editor Jon Hilsenrath. And CFRA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell. Lindsey, and with you -- begin with you first on your concerns about what's been happening with Turkey. A little bit of stability today, maybe Home Depot safe today in just a second, but what do you make of it?

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: The stability today is an encouraging development for sure. But like you said, the lira is down almost 50 percent year-to-date, that's a little bit shocking especially for this type of country.

But the issue here is that their country, they don't have government debt, they have debt that is coming from other countries and then is valued in the dollar. I mean, as the dollar rises, this is a problem. At CFRA we have -- we reduce our exposure to merging markets earlier this year because interest rates rising, the dollar is expected to rise. So that was an area we wanted to move away from.

But, you know, if you look at the overall -- the Wall Street Journal, Jon I'd love to hear your thoughts too, has a great article in there this morning too about how even though the fall that we've seen so far, the valuations of the -- of the debt and the equity markets are not at these very deep discounted levels.

So theoretically the story of the emerging markets may not entirely be over, although it has come down.

CAVUTO: You know, maybe just looking for that pause, right? At least something.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well you tend -- when you get these emerging market crisis, you tend to -- they tend to come in pulses and then you can have things stabilize for a few days but it doesn't mean by any stretch that Turkish problems are finished.

You know, as you said they have all this U.S. dollar debt, they have all the earmarks of an emerging market crisis. A lot of U.S. dollar debt, a falling currency, large current account debt --

CAVUTO: And by the way, we're stating the obvious here about the more currency tumbles against the dollar. In this case, the more it's going to take to, you know, get out of that hole.

HILSENRATH: Right. And we will -- we will talk about this --

CAVUTO: -- that stronger dollar just makes it more of a hole.

HILSENRATH: We were talking about this yesterday, the next sure to drop is the banks because the banks are exposed. You know, when interest rates rise we're seeing interest rates rise. A lot in Turkey when their currency falls loans go bad and you start to see banks destabilized. So that's where I'm looking next and --

CAVUTO: And this is 180 from what it was, right? I mean, when times are good the banks were loaning to anyone in -- you know --

HILSENRATH: And that's where it's getting all the trouble.

CAVUTO: And that's what complicated things, right? Yes.

HILSENRATH: Right. And then -- so then the other thing to look at is, do this go over into any other markets? You mention in the opening, South Africa, you have to be a little worried about. Argentina just got a big IMF loan to stabilize its economy and its financial markets, maybe Brazil, Russia.

But, you know, when you look at a lot of Turkish problems are unique to Turkey especially this fight that they've got going on right now with the United States over this American pastor. So it's possible that this is just a Turkish problem.

CAVUTO: By the way, if they released Pastor Andrew Brunson problems go away or no?

HILSENRATH: No, they have fundamental economic problems. They have -- as I -- yes, as I said they've got destabilized banking system --

CAVUTO: But our tariffs going to stop, right? Our tariffs would presumably stop.

HILSENRATH: Well -- so it could help and stabilize things a little bit because, you know, who knows maybe the president would reverse it, he just doubled the tariffs. Maybe he'd go back to where they were a few weeks ago.

They certainly would stop putting tightening the screws on the country, so that would give Erdogan a little bit more breathing room. But it doesn't sound like he's going to respond --

BELL: Which is going to hurt Turkey even more and that would be a major problem. But --

CAVUTO: But what if he was released today?

BELL: If you were to --

CAVUTO: Released today, the pastor were released today and that was the reason why the president double those tariffs on, you know, aluminum and metal related products.

BELL: Yes. I think that would be a positive sign for the country but I think that the issues have been building the concerns here --

CAVUTO: Yes.

BELL: -- for quite some time now. So I don't think that the story is over. It will -- it will be a little bit of a relief rally perhaps in the lira. But I think that they have bigger problems to deal with.

HILSENRATH: You know Neil, whenever we've written over the past few years about spasms in emerging markets whether it be Argentina or some other country and we start looking at what countries could be next, Turkey was always at the top of the list.

We were always talking about the economic fundamentals just weren't in good shape there. One of the problems there is the way they deal -- the way they manage the central bank, there's no central bank independence, a lot of concerns. Inflation is exceptionally high in Turkey, a lot of concerns there. The central bank let the currency go.

CAVUTO: So I'm curious, like what potentially saves the day? Home Depot is out with numbers that beat estimates right now. So that could -- that could be a catalyst or a good development, right?

I mean, we've been looking at retail as the sign of what the individual consumer is doing, I don't know whether Home Depot shoppers and now it's to Nordstrom shopper and a Macy shopper and a Walmart shopper. But that's been the backdrop for the president, right? That's been his position of strength.

BELL: Right. And you know what, last year at this time we were -- the whole market really assumed the retail was just a debt, this story was completely over and it's been revitalized. It's starting in the fourth quarter of last year.

Home Depot this morning be on top and bottom line, it's very impressive. They had a weaker first quarter report and that was because of whether, you know, you hate to blame the weather but the gardening business is really slow. So I suspect, I haven't seen all the details here but I'm guessing the gardening business was able to pick up with better weather.

And we're really expecting the retailers to do well this quarter because spending has rebound significantly in the second quarter. After taking a little bit of a break in the first quarter, you've got GDP 4.1 percent in the second quarter. Unemployment is at such low levels, confidence is high.

It's really just the perfect storm for retail right now even though these stocks, if you look at the S&P500 retail index, it's up over 30 percent year-to-date, much better --

CAVUTO: As earnings in the aggregate I mean they're --

BELL: Right.

CAVUTO: -- (INAUDIBLE) I think they're running at a -- close to 25 percent flip over last year, that's a lot stronger than people thought it would be.

BELL: Exactly. And, you know, it's going to continue through the second half of the year. Numbers have actually remained stable and that was something that was a concern. Tariffs and different things do political concerns on the forefront, but the numbers have been steady and going up actually.

HILSENRATH: You know, one of the big themes the last few years has been the death of retail because of Amazon and online shopping. And one of the surprises this year is that retail is hanging in there, you mentioned all these earnings numbers.

But when you look at the employment numbers, one of the fastest growing sectors for hiring right now is retail. It's really surprising retail and manufacturing are the two biggest employers for hiring. And, you know, the other thing I'd say is we have retail sales data coming out.

CAVUTO: That's true.

HILSENRATH: (INAUDIBLE) these earnings numbers tomorrow retail sales data coming out, so we'll see.

CAVUTO: I don't think there's a better barometer on the mood of the consumer than whether he or she is shopping, right? And then I'm wondering when you talk to your friends, you know, you're very cheap I know that --

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes.

CAVUTO: -- when you go out Kat. But the people are more predisposed to buy than they've been in many year and I'm wondering what you make of that.

TIMPF: I think that there is very high consumer confidence. But I am surprised about the brick and mortar stores actually doing decently well because I haven't gone to a store to buy a thing in probably years.

Even like toilet paper, paper towel, I get that all delivered via Amazon Prime. I don't like to leave my apartment probably more than the average bear. So I'm -- I guess some people might go to the store occasionally but --

CAVUTO: To physically go to any store.

TIMPF: I don't. I get --

CAVUTO: Really?

TIMPF: -- absolutely everything delivered to my apartment.

CAVUTO: Interesting.

TIMPF: Unless I'll have to try on shoes. I'll try on shoes and then I'll leave the store and buy them online for cheaper.

CAVUTO: But, you know, the people are -- I'm not saying they're shopping was abandoned but there -- you know, through all the vagaries and the crises and, you know, the Turkish disruptions and then the trade tariff disruption, one constant has been the consumer.

BELL: Yes. No. Absolutely has been true. And I think part of the thing too and I think part of the thing too is with the brick and mortar stores that they've been building out their direct consumer, their online businesses and you'll see -- we'll probably hear that through some of the second quarter earnings that they're still investing in and that there's worry that that might impact margins a little bit.

But the consumer is feeling good and they are shopping and that is definitely that big in the economy.

HILSENRATH: And they also have money in their pockets because they're withholding -- the government is withholding less from their paychecks for taxes because of the tax cuts last year.

CAVUTO: You know, this is the position the president has bragged about has been the win that is back and then that if you're going to go into a trade war, he doesn't call it a trade war, but if you're going to go into a fight, this is -- this is a position you want to be in. Do you guys buy that?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, the economy is strong right now so he is negotiating from a position of strength. The only thing -- you know, sorry to be a nervous Nellie but --

CAVUTO: You do have that reputation.

HILSENRATH: But we're building a very large budget deficits. We're talking about $1 trillion budget deficits and things feel good right now, let's talk again in --

CAVUTO: We've been building those up for quite a few years.

BELL: Nobody said they were going to coming -- they were coming down actually. You know, when republicans were in-charge of Congress they push the Obama Administration to squeeze spending.

So as a percent of GDP, the deficits were coming down but they're going back up. It's unprecedented how far --

CAVUTO: Would you blame that one -- some blame it on the tax cuts, others ignore the spending component of that. I mean --

HILSENRATH: Right. This Congress and this White House just increased -- you know, just get a big increase in government spending. And so -- and some of this stuff wanes in 2020, 2021.

CAVUTO: This is your paper if memory serves me right that pointed out that revenues from those tax cuts have been actually a pleasant surprise.

HILSENRATH: Well they were in June but -- they were in May I think but in June and July they soften a little bit.

CAVUTO: So you're not a believer yet?

HILSENRATH: No.

CAVUTO: You're challenging your own newspaper.

HILSENRATH: No.

CAVUTO: No, I'm kidding. I'm kidding. I'm kidding.

HILSENRATH: We reported what was the case in May but it was just one month. The last couple of months have been softer on the revenue side.

CAVUTO: Do you think those tax cuts are something that is explaining what's going on at Home Depot, explaining what could be going on at Walmart and Macy's and Dillard's and Nordstrom and all these other numbers that are due out in the next few days that that has really fueled all of this?

TIMPF: I think it depends on the person. I think that for some people that was a lot more money than it was for other people. I think for a lot of people that, you know, it does make a difference.

It was a huge chunk of change compared to what they're used to having but at the same time it does bother me that we did tax cuts without spending cuts because I remember when republicans were supposed to be the fiscally conservative party and always talking about the debt and the deficit and now it just turns out that they're adding to the deficit in different ways.

Which I certainly rather have a tax cut than more entitlement programs and everyone keep more of their own money than it is something that we need to be concerned about at some point.

HILSENRATH: We did tax cuts with spending increases.

TIMPF: Right.

CAVUTO: Right. We did the worst. Yes. I do find it odd though when we focus on the battle over taxes and spending and all that. You know, I think this budget has, what, almost $12 trillion in extra spending added to the debt in the next 10 years and yet everyone makes a big deal over one and a half to one to one and three quarter trillion in tax cuts and the revenue there and not something that's 10 times larger on spending.

BELL: I agree with you. I think you make a very good point and should continue to make that point on air. But it's -- it is in -- it is a concern because as the Fed is going to raise interest rates it's going to become a major problem.

But right now you're seeing the tenure thing below three percent which is being kind of crazy. And so the market doesn't really want have -- or individuals don't really have any reason to get too concerned yet and that's why I think people really just avoiding the topic.

HILSENRATH: So Lindsey, you mentioned the Fed -- the other thing that we have to look out for is relations between the White House and the Fed over the next couple of years. You know, not only -- and the Trump is -- the president has tweeted about this, about his discomfort --

CAVUTO: Absolutely.

HILSENRATH: -- with the Fed raising interest rates. But not only does it --

CAVUTO: He's not the first president frustration. He's just publicly stated it, right?

HILSENRATH: Right.

CAVUTO: Right.

HILSENRATH: And, you know, Lyndon Johnson famously --

CAVUTO: Absolutely.

HILSENRATH: -- you know, poked his finger as Fed chairman and said you can't -- you know, you're hurting my war effort. So -- but the worry here I think for the president is not only could it slow the economy, it makes it even more expensive to finance all this debt that we're building.

CAVUTO: That reminds me guys and I know we have to cut for break here pretty soon, but when you look at the -- let's say Home Depot is not a trend for the entire retail industry, I hasten to add that.

But if you're sitting at the Federal Reserve, you're looking at yet another piece of evidence that shows the economy picking up the same people (INAUDIBLE)/ going out and buying things, you know, willy-nilly. Does that get -- confirm your view that you have to keep raising rates?

BELL: I think it's more, you know, they're going to look to inflation which we saw has been ticking up. And they do believe that there will be some one off period or months that you'll see inflation above their two percent target, the core inflation number which we saw in the most recent reading.

But I think based on that they're going to act accordingly. The market right now is expecting two rate hikes at the end of this year. And I think that will --

CAVUTO: So two more this year.

BELL: Yes.

CAVUTO: And that still baked into the cake, do you agree with that Jon?

HILSENRATH: Absolutely. Yes. I think they go to two and a half or three percent and then they see how inflation is developing and if, you know --

CAVUTO: Two and a half or three percent in an overnight bank lending rate, right?

HILSENRATH: Right. Right.

CAVUTO: OK.

HILSENRATH: And then they see how inflation is developing and, you know, if it's continuing to rise they -- maybe they keep going. I think the plan right now is to keep going into next year to two and a half and three percent.

And it's going to be really interesting to see to watch the president's Twitter account to see how frustrated he's getting with those rate increases.

CAVUTO: Yes. Because it starts to wonder why you're -- is strong a good thing. You know Kat, we talk about sentiment and people's moods improving, when you talk to people, you do sneak out of your apartment. Are you getting any vibes from your friends, colleagues that, you know, something good could be going here.

I think I'm going to buy more and then I'm going to do more, you know, the kind of stuff that we -- we've had false starts prior but this seems to be a consistent pattern.

TIMPF: Absolutely. A lot more shopping, a lot more vacations. It seems actually looking on Instagram every now and then, I'm certain of my friends are literally always on vacation. Do you have any people like that that you know off that are just always posting from Bora Bora?

BELL: I do.

TIMPF: It's like, "OK, don't you have a job?" But, yes, I absolutely do think that there's higher confidence right now.

CAVUTO: OK. We're going to take a quick break here. We're going to get sort of the latest on what's happening right now in Turkey where at least for the time being calmer, cooler heads are prevailing.

Meantime, we'll give you the latest on this apparent car crash outside parliament in London. No one is calling this a terrorist incident, in fact, a few are characterizing it any -- which way. But it has happened again, raise concerns again and a lot of people getting nervous again. It's not being reflected in the market certainly but we're on top of it. More for this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right. We're still trying to find out more about this car that rammed a (INAUDIBLE) British Parliament. Cheryl Casone has much more on this. Cheryl, what happened?

CASONE: Well it's very interesting Neil. This all happened overnight out in London. At this stage Scotland Yard not calling it a terror attack but they're treating the incident as terrorism. They arrested the driver of the vehicle, they say he drove through crown of pedestrians and then crashed into a gate just outside of parliament as you mentioned.

Several were injured, streets in the surrounding area corned off in the nearby Westminster underground tube station has been closed. The area the site of a terror attack back in March of 2017 where Khalid Masood plowed a car into crowds on Westminster Bridge, you may remember that.

Four people died in that incident. We're, of course, going to provide more information as we get it out of our Fox London Bureau this morning.

Well here at home, motorists in four states are heading to the pole today, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Vermont, and Connecticut were holding primaries. In Wisconsin President Trump call for a boycott of Harley-Davidson that forced Governor Scott Walker and the republicans to either criticize the president or stick with the Milwaukee-based company. Eight democrats are buying to challenge walker.

And in Minnesota, Democratic Congressman Keith Ellison has been accused of emotionally and physically abusing his ex-girlfriend. He is running for the State Attorney General spot. He has several opponents in that race.

Now, one of the four Vermont Democrat seeking the party nomination for governor isn't even old enough to vote. Meet 14-year-old Ethan Sonnerborn. He -- now he does not meet the requirements to be in the -- actually he does meet the requirements in the ballot because his parents allowed him to do so.

He's taking his place with the state's more age-appropriate candidate. The state constitution doesn't have an age requirement for people seeking the state's highest office. He's taking full advantage.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ETHAN SONNERBORN (D), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE, VERMONT: I think my campaign transcend age. Only they'll think of me as pragmatic progressive who happen to be 14.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: He's 14. Ethan has raised just over $1,700. Unfortunately not enough to make him competitive and, yes, his parents had to allow him to get on the ballot.

OK. And then finally we're going to end with this Neil, check out the price of Bitcoin, the digital currency falling below $6,000 for the first time since June. At one point trading just above 5,800 bucks. Nearly every other cryptocurrency under pressure this morning.

Digital currency has, of course, rallied last month on hopes that new investors would be attracted to Bitcoin back ETF but the SEC has postponed a decision Neil on the phone. Remember when Bitcoin was $20,000?

CAVUTO: Wow.

CASONE: You can imagine that we question that at the time. Hmm.

CAVUTO: you know, I'm curious about this kid in Vermont. Not only because he looks like I did I would say but (INAUDIBLE). If he gets elected, he can be governor?

CASONE: Legally on the ballot. Yes. His parents had to sign off but he is legally on the ballot.

CAVUTO: Wow.

CASONE: Some with the legal community in the state have something to say about it possibly.

CAVUTO: Yes. All right. Well, it's Vermont. All right. Thank you very, very much. I always learned something Cheryl from your updates. We're on top of that.

We're also on top of another company on the verge at hitting $1 trillion market gap. In fact, they're lining up like claims at LaGuardia right now. Amazon could be the next; we're on it after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right. After Apple, Amazon? It could happen. $1 trillion in market value maybe sooner than you think. Lauren Simonetti is here. Lauren, good to see you back. Well they have another pleasure.

SIMONETTI: Good to see you. Welcome back to you as well Neil.

CAVUTO: Thank you.

SIMONETTI: Amazon will be a $1 trillion because the share price only has to go up seven percent and they do join Apple in the, $1 trillion club.

Forester Research out with a note and they say, "Look, Amazon's actually better than Apple because consumers like Amazon more. You know, it's -- you have your iPhone, you have your Apple T.V.

TIMPF: Amazon is the only reason I'm still alive, yes.

SIMONETTI: Well you're good with that. But with Amazon they just keep selling to you whether it's Alexa or a hardware or your -- you know, what - - your diapers, whatever you buy in Amazon. They are in so many different branches.

So Amazon should be next if you look at the latest numbers at the market capitalizations of the big tech stocks. So Apple had a million, trillion right now $940 billion. Google, Alphabet 875 billion. Look at Microsoft, $840 billion.

CAVUTO: It's been sneaking up there.

SIMONETTI: It has been sneaking up. Where's Facebook in all of this? Well, $524 billion is the market capitalization. So we are seeing in some senses a differentiation between the tech companies.

Not so popular among investors right now where the tech companies that are very reliant on advertising dollars. Hence Facebook not as popular as some of the others at this point in the game.

CAVUTO: You know what's interesting about it too, there used to be a time, right in a phonetic go-go late 90s internet (INAUDIBLE) that you invested on promise, not profit because they didn't have to make money. All of those names make money and a lot. ELMORE: Yes.

CAVUTO: So was it different now?

BELL: I think so. I mean, Amazon they've really -- they're using WF cloud business to fund the retail and other business and the other branches, they're getting their hand in --

SIMONETTI: Healthcare

BELL: -- in everything. Yes. Healthcare. So - mean, I think Amazon they're growth opportunity, they're probably much more significant than Apple.

CAVUTO: And they're taking all over the world.

HILSENRATH: I think it's totally different in the '90s.

CAVUTO: Yes.

HILSENRATH: You know, in the '90s almost anyone could IPO. All you needed was an idea and a few connections on Wall Street and you are (INAUDIBLE)

CAVUTO: That's right.

HILSENRATH: Now market has really dominated by just a few big companies. You know, Amazon, Apple. It's really interesting to see Microsoft on there though. Microsoft has really reinvented itself, yes.

CAVUTO: Completely.

HILSENRATH: Yes. We don't depend on Microsoft Office the way we used to but they manage to keep themselves relevant in a very fast changing environment.

CAVUTO: But I was noticing they all have a great reliance and very viable business on the cloud, you know, up there.

TIMPF: That's where it is.

CAVUTO: And I was wondering, where is all this stuff?

SIMONETTI: It's in the cloud.

TIMPF: In the cloud.

SIMONETTI: It's in the cloud.

CAVUTO: It's a very good name for it.

SIMONETTI: I spent $2.99 a month for my cloud of pictures.

TIMPF: But do you know how to actually access it? Do you know how to actually access it?

SIMONETTI: No. But my husband does, so we're good.

TIMPF: OK.

CAVUTO: Sure your kids would love one, yes.

HILSENRATH: In this data farms in like Utah and stuff. That's where -- it's actually on the ground. But --

CAVUTO: But that was the reason for Microsoft's turnaround, right?

HILSENRATH: I don't know with that. I'm still trying to figure out --

TIMPF: I don't know -- I know I have stuff in there but how do I ever see it? I'm spending the $2.99 too, I don't know why.

CAVUTO: Well maybe you just got to get out of your apartment and (INAUDIBLE).

BELL: Yes.

CAVUTO: You know what's weird about though -- and Jon when you were mentioning this, this idea that it's different from the late 1990s and that, you know these are money making ventures and have a clear business model. But are they rich to you? Even allowing for the --

BELL: Well, some of them do have high multiples, Amazon being one that (INAUDIBLE) other. But if you look at technology overall, the multiples about 19 times. By historical sandals it's not too bad. But you know, at the end of the day, Twitter is an approved medium for companies to make announcements. There is the idea that companies need to have some precedent in how they've made announcements on Twitter in the past, there's question around if Musk gets blocked people from following him, does that sort of preclude certain shareholders potentially from having access to that information? And I think all of those are going to be questions that SEC regulators are asking.

BELL: Well, Stefanie, we just saw the tweet of, you know, it seems like Tesla is working with some high-powered, you know, bankers: Goldman, Silver Lake advising on this deal, some lawyers as well. And this would be -- if this actually occurs, it could be the largest leveraged buyout of all-time at $70 billion. This is a company that doesn't really generate a lot of cash flow. In blog post yesterday, Elon Musk alluded to the fact that he was -- he's going to expect a lot of the equity players to hang around. If that is the case, the SEC is still going to have to review this company, it will be under the watch of the SEC. Do you think equity holders will be able -- will want to -- excuse me -- stick around and hold this stock through this process?

MILLER: You know, this is an interesting company and how unconventional its leader is. And a lot of people have sort of invested in him as much as in the company. It's hard to imagine that that sort of sentiment and the emotional attachment and sort of belief in what Elon Musk believes that that would go away just because of the structure of whether it's publicly or privately held. So, I have to think the regulatory scrutiny is obviously one thing, but there is a lot of evangelists out there, and it's hard for me to imagine that that goes away.

HILSENRATH: Stefanie, Tesla burns through cash, it's got short sellers coming after it, it's got a couple of bonds that are coming due, how serious are its cash-flow problems, and is it talking about it going private deal because it just basically needs to -- it needs more money?

MILLER: Yes, I mean, there's a lot of reasons why Tesla may want to go private. One would be just to have access to it -- to much more capital to help fund all of the ideas that its senior executive has. Another would just be to kind of come out from the scrutiny of being a publicly-held company which comes with a lot of strings attached for someone who is so creative. So, it does seem like there are multiple -- there would be multiple things that would make a buyout or a transition to a privately- held sort of entity very attractive for this specific company.

CAVUTO: Now, Elon Musk has 20 percent stake in the company as it stands now, right?

MILLER: Yes.

CAVUTO: OK. So, what would change if it's a private concern?

MILLER: For him? I don't think that he seem to change anything when it went public. I would -- I would -- it would be hard for me to imagine anything about him, his commitment to the company, or his -- you know, his vision for what the company means will change based off of the structure of how the capital is held.

CAVUTO: So, the other point I had -- we were discussing during the break is many of the attached -- maybe questionable attentions to his comments last week about Saudi funding and all the rest, couldn't he just be, you know, no unspoken thought, he has done this on analysts conference calls. There has -- there's nothing sinister afoot here, obviously not a smart thing to do, but as far as, you know, something Machiavellian or any of that, I guess might be pushing it.

MILLER: Agreed. Yes, this seems -- I think that one thing that investors in this company are pretty aware of, and a dozen of us who've been observing it from the outside are aware of is that the intentions seemed to be very, very good and pure, most of -- most of the time along the way even when the decisions made maybe leave us scratching our heads because of how unconventional or unconformist they are to how the rest of --

CAVUTO: You're right.

MILLER: -- rest of it is done.

CAVUTO: Well put. Stefanie, thank you very much. Kat, I was thinking to you and young people in general, the allure of electric cars, is it still there?

TIMPF: I don't know. I don't really think so. I don't have a car whatsoever, I don't even know anyone with an electric car. I mean, it's a little more complicated.

CAVUTO: But you again don't leave your apartment that much.

TIMPF: I don't leave my apartment, and when I do, I do have a driver's license, and I really, really shouldn't. I haven't driven in about five years.

CAVUTO: That's scary. All right, that is very, very scary. All right, in the meantime, we should alert you to some primaries, at least four states on Wisconsin -- I think this is the fourth attempt if you think about it, that they're going after Scott Walker, or at least deciding on who his Democratic challenger will be. I go back to 2010 when he was elected. 2011 when he's breaking up unions, 2012 the special elections, 2014 is re- election. Maybe this is the charm for them. That is just one state, one in yet in the Midwest. Blake Burman live from the White House on what's at stake. Hey, Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Neil, good morning to you. Minnesota, Vermont, Connecticut, and Wisconsin voters, if they haven't head to the polls, they're already this morning will do so today for primary day. Let me sort of tick through some of the headlines in each of those states heading into this -- in today's election. In Minnesota, for example, Congressman Ellison, he's on the ballot there, but to become that state's attorney general, he has been accused in the recent days of domestic violence against his ex-girlfriend which he denies.

If Christine Hallquist wins her primary in Vermont, she would become the country's first transgender gubernatorial candidate from a major political party. Republicans in Connecticut are eyeing the governor's mansion there, they see a potential opening to take that seat. But what really ties back here to the White House is what you talked about in the lead-in, Wisconsin, and a tweet from the President over the weekend threw a little bit of a wrench for Scott Walker who's up in the primary today, but likely has his eyes headed toward November, threw a wrench for walker other Republicans in that state.

Because over the weekend, the President sent out the following tweet as it relates to Harley-Davidson saying, "Many Harley-Davidson owners plan to boycott the company if manufacturing moves overseas. Great! Most other companies are coming in our direction, including Harley competitors, a really bad move. U.S. will soon have a level-playing field or better."

Now, Harley as you know, it is based in Milwaukee, it has threatened to move its manufacturing overseas. European production overseas because of President's trade policies. Here was Walker's response to the President's tweet, saying, "As I said yesterday, I want Harley-Davidson to prosper here in State of Wisconsin so, of course, I don't want a boycott of Harley- Davidson. And one of the best ways for that to happen is to do what the President has called for and that is to get no tariffs as soon as possible. By the way, Neil, last night, the President did go to Twitter to endorse walker, but this Harley-Davidson issue will not be going away any time soon, as Democrats will most certainly try to use it against Republicans in that state. Neil?

CAVUTO: All right, Blake Burman, thank you very, very much. (INAUDIBLE) you look at this back-and-forth and all these primaries, and they're going to sort out who's ultimately going to be on the ballot in the fall. When you talk about -- so, what's the latest gauge they have on the November election? How things are looking for Republicans, for Democrats, specifically governorships notwithstanding, it odds tonight, but more control of the House and Senate?

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean, the question is whether the Democrats get control of the House, and you know, on the one hand, they're very motivated because -- they're very motivated to challenge the President. On the other hand, Republicans have a really strong economy behind them and it's kind of hard to argue to kind of change the alignment of power right now when you have a 3.9 percent unemployment rate and growth, depending on how you measure around three percent.

TIMPF: A lot of passing though, a lot of people on the left that maybe didn't get out and vote in 2016 are going to get out there in '20 just because of what happened in 2016.

CAVUTO: And they've used these Ohio results, right, to say look, the guy is just eking out -- (INAUDIBLE) it's barely hanging on, you know?

TIMPF: I think there is a lot of passion on the Republican side, too, I think it's higher now than it has been in the past before midterms I think with one exception since 1994, Republican voter enthusiasm. So President Trump gets people really excited, whether it's for him or against him, there's definitely a lot of passion involved.

CAVUTO: Yes. Lindsey, if the House switch, became Democratic, market reaction would be?

BELL: It would still rally because -- again, because of certainty. Yes.

CAVUTO: Interesting. So, the reality of that happening wouldn't dissuade them.

TIMPF: Right.

HILSENRATH: I mean, wouldn't that lead to --

CAVUTO: Impeachment (INAUDIBLE)

HILSENRATH: Yes. Always talk about impeachment and a new kind of uncertainty.

BELL: Well, in that case, when Clinton -- the impeachment (INAUDIBLE) the star report came out and they were going through that, the market went down but by the time it went through the Senate, it -- the market was back towards --

HILSENRATH: That was one of the best times for the stock market in our history, late 1990s.

CAVUTO: Yes. There are some differences here with this particular -- we'll see. All right, Stuart Varney is coming up. Why the tanking U.S. economy is concerning. Stuart Varney -- joking. I'm joking. More after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

Stuart Varney weighs in on all of that. Stuart, what do you think of that?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: What are you doing, Neil? Three hours, 6:00 to 9:00, another two hours, 12:00 to 2:00, and another one hour, 4:00 to 5:00. I'm trying to do the math even I know that's not required for this program, but I think that looks to me like six hours of broadcasting in a single day. You know, they used to call me an air hog. I think it's you, Neil. But to answer your question, substantively --

VARNEY: OK. OK. We have very strong growth in America. We have a very strong economy. We'll see. What do you say, Neil?

CAVUTO: I can't spell Oxford. Now, you must know the risk and the lunacy involved here. Your thoughts.

VARNEY: Risk and lunacy? Can you show me evidence that our economy is either falling apart or slowing down because of intended tariffs?

VARNEY: Oh, I don't think it's that risky. I think the president is dealing some very strong hands --

CAVUTO: So, you're pro-tariff. Pro-tariff (INAUDIBLE)

VARNEY: I trust President Trump to negotiate from a position of strength and to come out with a good result. Something wrong with that?

urn:contentItem:5TNG-5YW1-DXY4-X296-00000-00Crazy Work Hours and Lots of Cameras: Silicon Valley Goes to China;The New New World2018-11-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESSCrazy Work Hours and Lots of Cameras: Silicon Valley Goes to ChinaThe New New WorldLi Yuan

A group of Silicon Valley executives went to China and discovered a parallel tech universe that can be equally impressive, alienating and dystopian.

One Chinese technology executive said he worked 14 to 15 hours a day at least six days a week. Another said he worked every waking hour and forced himself to watch movies to relax.

The reaction from a group of Silicon Valley executives: Wow.

“We’re so lazy in the U.S.!” blurted Wesley Chan, a venture capital investor, on the first day of what would be a weeklong journey into the Chinese technology scene.

Work habits weren’t the only sharp difference between the Valley and China. By the end of the week, a group of American executives and investors found an alternate tech universe. It resembles Silicon Valley superficially. Look closer, and it becomes a futuristic yet closed-off world that can be equally impressive, alienating and dystopian.

Chinese technology executives, they found, were even more driven and more willing to do whatever it takes to win. But that comes with major trade-offs, and punishing work schedules are only the beginning. They found Chinese tech executives to be less reflective about the social impact and potential misuse of their technologies, a potentially worrisome quality in a country with loosely enforced privacy laws,   strict government censorship and   a powerful domestic surveillance apparatus.

“It was impressive to see the pace of innovation in China,” said Mark Goldberg, a partner at Index Ventures, a venture capital firm. “Some of the newer technologies, like facial recognition software, can be very powerful, and will need to be deployed thoughtfully — not just in China, but also in the West.”

In August, Mr. Chan, Mr. Goldberg and 11 other Silicon Valley investors and start-up founders took a trip to Beijing and Shenzhen, two cities that are competing for the title of the Silicon Valley of China. Organized by the venture capital firms Basis Set Ventures, Index Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank, it was intended to help them understand how China has become a tech rival to the United States in barely two decades.

Silicon Valley once saw China as a copycat, but it now has some of the world’s biggest and most powerful internet companies. It   has more unicorns, or privately held companies with valuations of over $1 billion, than the United States. The China offices of venture capital firms like Sequoia Capital now manage bigger funds than their American headquarters. Silicon Valley luminaries like   Michael Moritz of Sequoia Capital have been urging American entrepreneurs and investors to learn from China’s work ethic, ambition and technological advances.

The Americans got upfront lessons on how quickly China embraced mobile phones,   electronic payments and   video streaming, and how intensely it has pursued artificial intelligence.

“I live in San Francisco, but I find it helpful to visit the other parallel universe from time to time,” said Lan Xuezhao, founding partner of Basis Set Ventures, who was born in China and visits the country every year. “To some degree, it’s like looking into the future.”

It started the moment the group members entered their rooms at the Park Hyatt Hotel in Beijing’s central business district, where a notice listed some of the websites they would be unable to call up “due to Chinese internet regulations”: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, Google, Bloomberg and The New York Times.

Online payments represented another telling metaphor. Mobile payments are almost ubiquitous in the biggest Chinese cities, but setting up an account requires a local mobile number and a Chinese bank account.

One afternoon they were desperate for caffeine and spotted a Luckin Coffee outlet, an up-and-coming Chinese brand, in the canteen of   Bytedance, the A.I. information and entertainment powerhouse. But Luckin takes orders only on its mobile app. At the cashier-less convenience store at the headquarters of   JD.com, the online retailer, an employee paid for their snacks with his own phone.

“China’s internet is a walled garden,” Mr. Chan said. “No one can break in unless you’re from here.”

Within that walled garden, everything seemed to be moving at an extraordinary speed. While Silicon Valley start-ups raise funding every 18 to 24 months on average, the group was told that the most successful Chinese companies do it every six months. It isn’t unusual for a hot start-up to raise funding three to four times a year.

“Every time I go to the U.S., I feel that I’ll need to grow 10 times faster,” said Alexander Weidauer, a founder of the Berlin-based A.I. chatbot developer Rasa and the only member of the group not from Silicon Valley. “Now I feel I’ll need to grow 100 times faster. The pace in China is crazy.”

Their hosts kept reminding them of the advantages China had over the United States in A.I. development. China’s vast population and loose privacy laws give them access to much more data. A.I. companies also have considerable government support and are willing to pay more for top talent.

“The U.S. competitive edge over China may not be long,” Kai-Fu Lee, chief executive of Sinovation Ventures and former head of Google China, told them. “In fact,” he added, “the Americans now have the information disadvantage.”

But it was also obvious to the group what China was missing. For starters, everybody is Chinese. Even in its early days, Google had employees from 39 nationalities speaking 40-plus languages.

“China is a bit homogeneous,” said Mr. Chan, an early Google employee. “You don’t find as much the perspectives of the world here compared to Silicon Valley.”

Then there are the work schedules. The Silicon Valley natives were introduced to the Chinese start-up concept of 996: Work from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., six days a week. Once they got over their shock, they had to ask: Does that punishing schedule make sense?

“I’m not worried so much about my portfolio companies not working as hard as the Chinese companies,” said Mr. Chan, now a partner at Felicis Ventures. “I’ll worry when they’re less creative and less efficient.”

While China is becoming more innovative, many members of the group said they believed — and some of their Chinese counterparts agreed — that the United States still led in some areas.

Although some Chinese tech companies can look very Silicon Valley-esque — with sprawling campuses that include dining halls, gyms and nap rooms — their preferred management style is still top down and results driven. Unlike Silicon Valley, smart underlings have less freedom to start something new.

Underscoring their admiration for strong leaders, the Chinese technology figures told the Silicon Valley group that many in China idolized the Uber founder Travis Kalanick, who resigned as chief executive last year after the company was embroiled in various scandals. The reason:   In his battles with a bigger local rival, Mr. Kalanick could be as aggressive and scrappy as a Chinese boss.

There was very little discussion about the consequences of Chinese companies’ ruthless focus on growth and the social impact of the technologies they develop — criticism Silicon Valley now faces. The visitors asked how Chinese companies dealt with the issues of censorship and algorithm-driven social media, but their hosts either seemed puzzled by the questions or brushed them off.

Technology itself is neutral, some of the Chinese executives said. It depends on how people use it — an argument that Silicon Valley companies used to make.

And then there was the surveillance. Chinese companies have little choice but to cooperate with Beijing’s growing efforts to track the daily lives of its own people. Some, in fact, make money off it.

Still, the Silicon Valley delegation did not expect facial recognition technology to be so widespread in Chinese life. Companies they visited used it at office entrances and at retail kiosks inside their facilities. They also saw demo videos of how the Chinese police could use the technology to monitor potential crimes in crowded public spaces and learn how many suspects had been arrested.

After grasping how prevalent the cameras were, they started counting them. Even the van they rented from the hotel in Shenzhen had a handful of cameras installed, blinking from time to time to signal that they were on.

Then, like many people in China, they got used to it, as if the cameras weren’t even there.

urn:contentItem:5WGR-9C31-DYTH-G1KP-00000-00CRC'S ONLINE SYMPOSIUM ON TECH CENSORSHIP2019-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisCRC'S ONLINE SYMPOSIUM ON TECH CENSORSHIPStates News ServiceWASHINGTON, DC

The following information was released by Capital Research Center (CRC):

How should politically minded users respond to the daily social media outrages that sweep the internet? Those on the Right are of differing minds as to how best respond to decisions made by tech companies and online publishers in an effort to accommodate advertisers or maintain privately adopted community standards, standards which read as outright ideological discrimination to many.

Republicans and conservatives point to instances of genuinely biased political decisions on the part of media companies, political commentators, and tech companies, and see the need to assert their right to public discourse. Some call for a sort of "fairness doctrine" to govern social mediain essence treating online forums as a public utility. Others wish to hold social media companies financially liable for what people post on sites like Facebook and Twitter. Those who object to tech companies' enforcement of community standards point out that they are vague and therefore inconsistently applied. What's worse, the "purge" of unsavory internet personalities might not stop with neo-Nazis and Klan members. Shrill internet activists have been known to incite communities to report certain accounts en masse, hoping that website moderators will do the dirty work and suspend or de-verify accounts from prominent commentators with differing ideologies.

Americans prize their First Amendment rights, which among other things guarantee citizens' right to free speech, association, and exercise of religion against government interference. At first glance, viewpoint discrimination and online censorship on public forums looks like an open-and-shut case of censorshipanti-American, bad for civic education, and fundamentally unfair. However, right-of-center folks also rightly note that companies like YouTube, Google, and Patreon are privately held entities that are also entitled to First Amendment rights, including the right not to associate with certain people or viewpoints. Those inclined to keep government small, also fear that any move to bring balance to online forums will instead empower the government to exert its own form of censorship.

These important considerations enjoy robust debate at the Capital Research Center. In the interest of furthering constructive debate and modeling civil discourse, CRC decided to host an online symposium on the issues of tech censorship and hear differing views on how best to combine concerns about free expression with concerns about free association. We hope you enjoy these considerations.

Big Tech and the Threat of Unperson-ing, Ashley Rae Goldenberg

Facebook Phobia: Social Media's Bias is Profits Not Politics, Ken Braun

De-platforming, The Power Of Left-Wing Media, And Their Right-Wing Allies, Joseph (Jake) Klien

Be Careful of Rush for Tech Regulation, Michael Watson

The articles and the opinions therein are the work of individual authors and do not reflect institutional views on the part of the Capital Research Center.

urn:contentItem:5XCV-WJ61-DXKP-J54N-00000-00Creating a new federal agency to regulate Big Tech would be a disaster2019-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisCreating a new federal agency to regulate Big Tech would be a disasterNeil Chilson

Have you ever accidentally shared a picture or a message with the wrong audience on Facebook? Have you wondered why social media sites show ads for something you recently purchased on an unrelated website? Are you concerned that your son or daughter might be getting addicted to an app or a game on their phone?

The Internet generates legitimate concerns about privacy, safety, fairness and misinformation. It's good we are having a national discussion about how best to address such concerns. But when someone suggests we need a law to solve our problems, it's time to pause and take a breath. And take another breath - or maybe book a meditation retreat - if someone claims we need a whole new federal bureaucracy.

But that's exactly what some have done. Scholars at the University of Chicago's Stigler Center recently called for the creation of a new federal Digital Authority to oversee everything from privacy and mergers to discrimination and online addiction. Reps. Zoe Lofgren (D-Calif.) and Anna G. Eshoo (D-Calif.) have a similar proposal for a 1,600-employee U.S. Digital Privacy Agency, which would regulate the way tech companies handle data. President Barack Obama's chief economic adviser Jason Furman wrote for the U.K. competition authority a report suggesting a new digital regulator might be needed. Australia's competition regulator recently recommended something similar.

On its face, a single expert agency, laser-focused on one set of problems, sounds sensible. But history shows that such industry-specific agencies are most susceptible to "regulatory capture," a term used to describe when an institution is dominated by the industry they are charged with overseeing - for example, when a state board that sets the rules for the practice of dentistry is dominated by practicing dentists.

The idea was popularized by the Stigler Center's namesake, Nobel economist George Stigler, who argued that "regulation is acquired by the industry and is designed and operated primarily for its benefit." In his foundational paper "The Theory of Economic Regulation," Stigler warned that any regulated industry has strong incentives to form close connections with its regulators to seek favors. The inevitable result, he argues, is that industries disproportionately influence the agency's agenda, shape its rulemaking and even supply it with personnel.

Companies find it much easier to influence narrowly focused institutions than institutions with broader law enforcement mandates. Where the latter hear from a wide range of companies with a variety of concerns, the former hear only from one type of company. Think about how much easier it is to talk your way out of a speeding ticket from the local police officer, who knows your family, than it is to deal with an effectively anonymous city cop who pulls over dozens of drivers a day. Similarly, big companies would much rather deal with a select group of bureaucrats whom they know well - and who hear only their perspective most of the time.

Captured agencies don't hold companies accountable; instead, they act to benefit the industry's established players, disadvantaging newer firms and the public at large. In worst-case scenarios, such agencies can block new, disruptive competitors that threaten the established, regulated industry.

The recent report from the Stigler Center holds up the Federal Communications Commission as an example of what a new Digital Authority could look like. But the FCC is a perfect example of the likely problems of an industry-specific regulator. At nearly every turn, with every new potentially disruptive communications innovation, the FCC (and its predecessor, the Federal Radio Commission) did the bidding of the best-connected incumbents. As former FCC chairman Michael Powell said, "[T]he history of the FCC is, when something happens that it doesn't understand, kill it. We tried to kill cable. We tried to kill long-distance. When [MCI founder] Bill McGowan start[ed] stringing out microwave towers that threatened AT&T, the FCC tried to stop him. The FCC tried to kill cable because it was going to threaten broadcasting." While it didn't halt technological progress or competition, it often slowed it, occasionally by decades.

For example, almost immediately after its creation, the Federal Radio Commission sided with industry players when it rejected the expansion of AM radio bands at the behest of existing commercial broadcasters. Later, the agency slowed the development of FM radio to protect AM radio manufacturers. It cracked down on early "community antenna television" (cable TV) to protect the broadcast television industry; conducted "beauty contests" to parcel out valuable broadcast licenses, sometimes to the politically connected (such as President Lyndon Johnson's wife); and slowed approvals and imposed onerous regulations on satellite radio services to protect traditional radio stations. The FCC also transfers billions of consumer dollars between various telecommunication competitors in pursuit of several different connectivity goals - an exercise that brings everyone to Washington to petition the FCC for a share of the money.

Thinking forward, the FCC's history suggests that a single digital regulator would make it easier for existing companies to lobby for processes that restrict new competitors. Even regulations that are intended to promote competition could easily become barriers to new competitors. Similarly, new digital business models could be delayed or blocked by regulators who are too familiar with the existing way of doing things to imagine new pathways to success.

Then there's the question of price controls: Fixing prices with competitors is anticompetitive - unless the government is the one setting the prices. And where private price-fixing agreements are unstable (since it only takes one defecting party to ruin the agreement), government-mandated prices are conveniently government-enforced. A single digital regulator could provide a simple mechanism for guaranteed profits. Imagine a digital ad industry regulated like the FCC regulated the AT&T telephone monopoly for more than 40 years.

So what is the alternative? As I noted earlier, regulators are less susceptible to the interests of individual companies and interests when they hear from a lot of different companies with a lot of different interests. Thus, generalist agencies that broadly regulate many industries are more resistant to capture. Further, agencies that primarily enforce laws (like the DOJ) are far less attractive targets for regulatory capture than those that mostly write rules (like the FCC). A company that manages to get in bed with the former might be able to dodge a lawsuit or put pressure on a competitor, but that pales before the possibility of influencing rules that reshape a company's entire industry.

In the United States, we already have an economywide enforcement agency: the Federal Trade Commission. Charged by Congress to promote competition and to protect consumers, the FTC has decades of experience addressing antitrust and consumer protection issues in the tech industry. Even now, it is pursuing investigations into digital companies under its current authority. And if new capabilities are needed to police digital companies, doesn't it make sense to give such authority to an experienced agency that has been resistant to regulatory capture?

Like many Americans, I am concerned about today's Internet-related challenges. But I hope our representatives will take a breath and focus on using and improving the tools we already have.

urn:contentItem:60G7-NX81-JCH9-G125-00000-00Creative hubs vs remote work2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisCreative hubs vs remote work

Four months ago, managers and employees at many companies went home and did something incredible: They got their work done, seemingly without missing a beat. Executives were amazed at how well their workers performed remotely, even while juggling childcare and the distractions of home. Twitter Inc. and Facebook Inc., among others, quickly said they would embrace remote work long term. Some companies even vowed to give up their physical office spaces entirely.

Now, as the work-from-home (WFH) experiment stretches on, some cracks are starting. Companies begin to think that remote work is not so great after all. Projects take longer, collaboration is harder, and training and integrating new employees is more complicated.

And I would like to share with you the negative side of remote work. There may be no richer creative hub story than this:

It was 2004, Mark Zuckerberg's summer of craziness. At 20, he and five buddies had rented a Palo Alto home, where they partied and wrote code for Facebook. One day, as Zuckerberg and the guys were strolling the neighborhood, he saw a familiar face. It was Sean Parker, the cofounder of Napster, the music sharing service. By coincidence, Parker, at loose ends and contemplating his next move, was staying at his girlfriend's parents' house, just up the street from the Facebook pad. The very next week, the big-thinking, smooth-talking Parker moved in with Zuckerberg and began introducing him around Silicon Valley. By the end of the summer, he had paved the way to Facebook's first big investment-$500,000 from Peter Thiel.

Thiel met 23-year-old Ukrainian immigrant named Max Levchin a few years earlier. After a bit of chatting, Thiel asked why the young man was in town. 'Probably gonna start a company,' Levchin said. 'Oh, great,' Thiel replied, and suggested the two meet up the next day and talk more over smoothies. And the consequence?

In 2002, eBay paid $1.5 billion for the resulting start-up-PayPal, making the two men and several partners rich. Over the subsequent years, PayPal vets including Thiel, Elon Musk, and Reid Hoffman went on to found YouTube, Tesla, SpaceX, LinkedIn, Yelp, and Palantir.

Perhaps no phenomenon is more studied, marveled, and desired in the world of high tech and science than the mystery of serendipity. My Oxford Dictionary explains serendipity as, 'The faculty of making happy and unexpected discoveries by accident.'

But now Silicon Valley seems to be under a little-noticed threat. Amid Covid-19, the deep recession, and renewed antitrust pressure from Congress and regulators, the Valley faces a very different challenge-the disruption of its very essence, the serendipitous encounter. The culprit is a rush by many of the Valley's leading companies to permanently lock in the coronavirus-led shift to remote work.

If engineers, designers, and venture capitalists are geographically disbanding, working via the cloud instead of walking Google's halls, surfacing at Buck's Restaurant, or the cafes on University Avenue, how will future serendipity happen?

If the founders, engineers, and designers in such startups are laboring entirely or largely from their own homes, and miss their moment, doesn't Big Tech potentially lose its next big growth engine?

Entrepreneurs say that, at least currently, the answer is yes-the WFH mandate has probably put classic serendipity out of reach for Silicon Valley's budding companies, and for companies in other tech centers/start-up villages.

No one knows exactly what such a new system might look like. If a demise of serendipity leads to Silicon Valley's decline, the world is unlikely to get an equal substitute. We may simply lose our engine of technological advancement.

If the past is instructive, the pandemic will pass and many daily routines will return. Hordes of people will return to the office, but large numbers won't. Some will pick up and move. At that point, today's effort to digitalize serendipity will pick up more urgency. Videoconferencing and other software will get better, and some companies will claim their product fosters the unscripted moment in truly innovative ways, blind to demographics.

The message I am trying to get across with these examples is that in the Philippines we need to culture serendipity in our creative enclaves in Cebu, Makati, Pasig, Quezon City, Iloilo, Baguio, Cagayan de Oro, and a few more. We will have to find a smart balance between people working from home and people to 'bump' into each other to discuss 'crazy' ideas and developments. And we need to save the start-up ecosystem.

However, while we protect and preserve the opportunities for social interaction, being the key to group creativity and innovation, we wish to see government to find the right balance between public health and economic and social health.

Let me have your views on this; e-mail me at [email protected]

urn:contentItem:5XKF-3C31-F11P-X333-00000-00Creator of the web reveals plan to save the internet from itself2019-11-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisCreator of the web reveals plan to save the internet from itselfDarren Allan

Tim Berners-Lee has revealed a contract calling for a new web with better privacy and no censorship.

Tim Berners-Lee, the creator of the web, was talking about a new plan for the worldwide web last year, to defend it from ‘sources of dysfunction’, and that contract – yes, it’s that official – has now been revealed.

The Contract for the Web sets out a number of core guiding principles for governments, companies, and users of the web themselves, to try and make the online landscape a better place on a number of different fronts.

The hidden limits of 'unlimited' web hosting
Best free web hosting of 2019
The best web browsers you can get

Tech giants will actually have to sign up to support the contract – which comprises of 76 clauses in total – and actively abide by it (or at least that’s the theory). Google, Facebook and Microsoft are among the big tech giants to have already signed up, among 150+ other firms, although names notably missing at this point include Amazon and Apple.

So what are the principles? Governments are tasked with ensuring that all citizens can connect to the internet, and that all of the internet must be available to them, all of the time. In other words, every individual must be able to get online, and there should be no censorship.

Any interference in terms of what can be accessed on the internet should “only [be] done in ways consistent with human rights law”, the contract notes.

Those are some big goals, of course, and policies that clearly won’t go down well in some corners of the world.

In terms of making sure every citizen across the globe has an internet connection, the contract lays out a guideline of access to broadband being available to at least 90% of citizens by 2030. Companies are also called on to make internet access more affordable, to that end.

Privacy push

There’s another major push on the privacy front, as you might expect, with the call for both governments and companies to respect and protect the online privacy rights of those who use the web.

The call to companies, and doubtless the bit that the likes of Google, Facebook and Microsoft are scrutinizing in particular, asserts what you’d expect in terms of clear explanations of any processes which affect user data and privacy, and the provision of control panels to manage data and privacy options in an easily accessible manner.

There’s also a stipulation that firms should carry out “regular and pro-active data processing impact assessments that are made available to regulators which hold companies accountable for review and scrutiny, to understand how their products and services could better support users’ privacy and data rights”.

Just as interesting is the section which calls for “minimizing data collection to what is adequate, relevant, and necessary in relation to the specified, explicit and legitimate purposes for which the data is processed”.

It doesn’t stop there, though. A further point is to support independent research on how interface designs affect the process of getting consent from users (as well as other considerations) and how these could “influence privacy outcomes”. In other words, this sounds like a call for no more sneaky wording or other potentially misleading UI tricks we’ve seen in the past (like clicking on a cross icon being taken as consent for an OS upgrade).

The contract also says that there should be controls over how personal data is collected, and also used, which can easily be viewed and adjusted by the user.

Big asks

There are some pretty big asks, then, on the privacy front, and it will certainly be interesting to see how this affects the tech giants who have signed up to the contract going forward. The natural cynical assumption might be that this won’t realistically happen, at least not as it’s laid down in black-and-white here.

However, if the companies who have signed up to the contract can’t show that they are indeed implementing the principles, and working to move forward with them, they may face being booted out from the group of organizations backing the plan. Which may well cast a shadow on the public perception of a firm, if it were to happen…

As Berners-Lee told the Guardian: “If we leave the web as it is, there’s a very large number of things that will go wrong. We could end up with a digital dystopia if we don’t turn things around. It’s not that we need a 10-year plan for the web, we need to turn the web around now.”

A raft of other measures in the contract include the requirement to diversify workforces, and laudable measures to help bring forward a more inclusive web built around strong communities that respect human dignity.

There are a lot of good intentions set out in the contract, that much is clear, but how this all translates into reality as we move forward remains to be seen. Skepticism aside, it’s easy to believe that at least some good will come of it – and hopefully much more than some good…

urn:contentItem:5WCG-BV51-F03R-W1MX-00000-00Crece la tensión entre bancos y las fintech por regulación del sistema2019-06-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisCrece la tensión entre bancos y las fintech por regulación del sistemaANA CLARAPEDOTTI


De un mutuo recelo al comienzo, bancos y fintech pasaron a una convivencia pacífica en los últimos años en el sistema financiero. Hasta que hace un par de semanas, la rivalidad entre ambos sectores volvió a tomar relevancia. Y ayer estalló.


En el centro del debate está la necesidad de regular o no a las compañías tecnológicas que trabajan en el sistema financiero. Según argumentan los bancos, las fintech no tienen las mismas obligaciones impositivas ni normativas que la banca tradicional.
Así, la semana pasada el presidente de la Asociación de Bancos Argentinos (Adeba), Javier Bolzico, se refirió en un discurso a las "asimetrías" y anunció que había presentado "una propuesta política" para "nivelar la cancha" entre todos los jugadores.
Adeba se basó en un informe redactado a su pedido por la consultora FIEL, que ponía el ojo más bien en el rol dentro del sistema local del gigante Mercado Libre, al que identificó como Big Tech, categoría que comparte con las grandes tecnológicas multinacionales como Google, Amazon, Facebook y Apple.
La respuesta de las fintech no se demoró. Ayer, la entidad empresaria que nuclea a más de 160 compañías del sector, emitió un duro comunicado en respuesta. "Desde la Cámara Argentina de Fintech nos parece oportuno reiterar, como venimos haciendo desde nuestra fundación en octubre de 2017, que sólo a través de la colaboración con el sistema financiero tradicional podremos encarar los desafíos de inclusión financiera con los que nos interpela la realidad argentina actual", puntualizaron.
Juan Pablo Bruzzo, presidente de la asociación, lo explicó a El Cronista: "Nos pareció importante sentar una posición para aclarar varios puntos que toma el comunicado de Adeba, que se prestan a confusión".
El también CEO de la fintech de pago Moni dijo: "Adeba habla las fintech como si fuera un sólo gran jugador, cuando es un colectivo que incluye muchos verticales (pagos y transferencias, financiamiento colectivo, préstamos, servicios fintech B2B, insurtech, inversiones, seguridad informática y blockchain y criptomonedas). Algunos están regulados, como el caso de las insurtech por la SuperIntendencia de Seguros o los brokers, por la CNV. Otros, que trabajan en lo que está más ligado al negocio bancario tradicional, no lo están por el Banco Central porque no hacen lo que se llama intermediación financiera. Pero sí, se ajustan a las normas que el regulador le impone al sistema".
Mientras el tono de la discusión aumenta, el Banco Central afirmó que "No hará comentarios sobre este tema por el momento".
El debate se trasladó a las redes sociales. Mientras el comunicado de la Cámara era distrbuido, el VP ejecutivo de Mercado Pago y mano derecha de Marcos Galperín, Osvaldo Gimenez, eligió responderle a Adeba con el hashtag: "No lo hizo un banco" en su cuenta de Twiter. "Hace décadas que la inclusión financiera en Argentina es bajísima. Es más fácil excusarse en la falta de regulación, que innovar y competir", escribió. "Innovamos creando un QR interoperable, se lo ofrecimos gratis a los comercios y en 12 meses ya hubo más de 8 millones de pagos desde celulares".
En conversación con este diario, Gimenez destacó que los productos de su compañía "están incluyendo financieramente a millones de personas" y que estos desarrollos surgieron "sin la necesidad de ningún arbitraje regulatorio como dan a entender los bancos".
Gimenez afirmó que muchas de sus iniciativas, como los pagos QR, apuntan a reemplazar el efectivo, no a desterrar a los bancos. "Lo que pasó fue que la competencia hizo que bajen los precios. En la Argentina, antes de que lancemos nuestros POS Móviles, estos se alquilaban y el alquiler costaba entre u$s 20 y u$s 30 por mes. Esto hacía que el parque total de terminales de pagos sea de alrededor de 800.000; mientras que nosotros, desde que salimos, ya vendimos más de 900.000 POS. El secreto es que lo vendemos por debajo del costo y sin alquiler mensual".
"Hay que competir, y habrá que hacerlo con márgenes que serán cada vez menores, pero es importante hacerlo para aumentar la proporción de personas que acceden a los sistemas financieros", dijo Gímenez.
La pregunta es si el fuego cruzado entre ambos bandos quebrará los espacios de diálogo que los reguladores habían generado, como la Mesa de Innovación Fintech a cargo del BCRA. Tanto en el Central como en la Cámara Fintech aseguraron que el espacio de trabajo conjunto se mantendrá sin cambios.
 
Más impuestos para la inclusión financiera
Hay un punto en que tanto el Banco Central, como los bancos privados y las fintech están de acuerdo: menos de la mitad de la población argentina posee acceso al mercado de crédito. Y consideran que es clave hacer crecer el índice de inclusión financiera.
Esta es, según una definición de la OCDE, la promoción de un acceso alcanzable a una amplia gana de servicios financieros y la ampliación de su uso hacia todos los sectores de la sociedad.
La torta de los no bancarizados o subbancarizados es el negocio que puede hacer crecer al sistema financiero local y a su vez, ampliar el nivel de formalidad de la población, clave para aliviar la fuerte presión impositiva.
Justamente, el tratamiento impositivo es uno de los puntos en los que los bancos reclaman la "desigualdad de condiciones".
Un viejo reclamo que se actualizó cuando en las últimas semanas se creó la Ley de Economía del Conocimiento, que le da ventajas tributarias a empresas que generen "empleo de valor agregado". La queja de las entidades "tradicionales" en este aspecto es que "no puede dársele el mismo incentivo impositivo a una startup que recién está comenzando, que a una empresa tecnológica gigante".
El sector fintech responde que sus compañías, diversas en sus modelos de negocios, cumplen con los regímenes impositivos. Pero que, además, incluir a más cantidad de personas al mundo de los pagos, contribuye a incrementar la formalidad de la economía.

urn:contentItem:5VST-PHG1-JBDN-31C2-00000-00Credit Suisse Thinks Spotify's Expectations Are Too High2019-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisCredit Suisse Thinks Spotify's Expectations Are Too HighDave Royse

Late last week, Credit Suisse initiated coverage of Spotify Technology SA(NYSE: SPOT) on the bearish side, saying the streaming service needs to face the music that expectations for long-term subscriber levels are too high.

The Analyst

Credit Suisse analyst Brian Russo on Friday started Spotify with an Underperform rating and $120 price target.

The Thesis

Long-term consensus subscriber estimates are too high and it will be tough for the company to get margins that meet consensus expectations, Russo wrote in last week's note.

The total addressable market is big, but Russo says the firm sees music streaming moving more toward household subscriptions, rather than individual plans, which puts Wall Street estimates for how many people will sign up for Spotify higher than Russo thinks reasonable.

Even if Spotify keeps its current market share of about 31 percent tough against competition from Apple Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL), Amazon.com, Inc. (NASDAQ: AMZN) and Alphabet Inc.(NASDAQ: GOOGL) s YouTube consensus forecasts for subscribers would mean half of all households in North America and Latin America would have to pay for streaming music by 2023.

This seems aggressive to us given intense competition and the popularity of free music services, and our longer-term SPOT sub forecast is below consensus, Russo wrote.

Russo noted that regulatory concerns for the big tech companies and a shift in leverage toward music content owners (and away from distributors) also don t bode particularly well for Spotify.

Price Action

Spotify's stock was trading up about 1 percent at $139.96 at publication time Monday.
