urn:contentItem:5WGM-B1P1-DXH2-6101-00000-00Crisis on the Border; Helping America's Heroes; Appeals Court Rejects Request to Delay Arguments in Obamacare Lawsuit; Massive Fire at Jim Bream Facility in Kentucky; Waymo gets the Green Light to Carry People in its Self-Driving Cars; Taco Bell Hit by Tortilla Shortage; July 4th Travel Weekend2019-07-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTRonica Cleary, Michael Block, Tom Homan, Shawn Handrahan, Marie Fishpaw, Mark EllwoodNEWSFinancial070302cb.231Crisis on the Border; Helping America's Heroes; Appeals Court Rejects Request to Delay Arguments in Obamacare Lawsuit; Massive Fire at Jim Bream Facility in Kentucky; Waymo gets the Green Light to Carry People in its Self-Driving Cars; Taco Bell Hit by Tortilla Shortage; July 4th Travel WeekendDagen McDowell, Deirdre Bolton, Cheryl Casone, Lauren Simonetti

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, July 3rd.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

Futures are showing gains across the board. A 61-point gain on the Dow futures. The markets will be closed tomorrow just for one day for the July 4th holiday here in the U.S. The S&P up 8 points in futures trading. The S&P of course, closed at another all-time high yesterday, second record in a row. The Dow and Nasdaq gaining as well.

In Europe, we have gains across the board to tell you about. In England, France and Germany, all those markets up more than six-tenths of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, different story -- selling across the board as hopes of a U.S.-China trade deal begin to fade a bit there. The biggest loser the Kospi in South Korea, off by nearly one and a quarter percent.

Healthcare in America -- attempts to block next week's Obamacare hearing fail. The hearing is a go. This as some drugs soar in price despite the President's promise that, well, he would keep drug costs in check, bring them down. A look at what is at stake.

Jim Beam up in flames, a major fire at its Kentucky bourbon warehouse. The latest on that blaze ahead in Woodford County, Kentucky.

Trouble for Facebook's crypto currency, House lawmakers asking the social media giant to put Libra on hold. The reasons why ahead.

Plus Crocs teaming up with a bad designer. Its new summer shoe getting a makeover and they don't look any better.

Here with me to break it all down this morning. Fox Business Network's Deirdre Bolton --

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Yes. Those Crocs are a little tough, I think. The flip flops are ok.

MCDOWELL: Market strategist, ThirdSeven Advisors --

(CROSSTALKING)

BOLTON: No comment.

MCDOWELL: Mike Block.

I'm trying not to be so negative. And the president of Cleary Strategies, former White House correspondent Ronica Cleary. I was very positive about the women's soccer celebration.

RONICA CLEARY, PRESIDENT, CLEARY STRATEGIES: Yes, you were.

MCDOWELL: Again, there is no such thing --

CLEARY: Unrelated to Crocs we might add.

I would just be -- absolutely hideous.

I want to talk about markets really quickly.

S&P, Mike Block -- at an all-time high. And the 10-year treasury yield--

BOLTON: Two-year low, right.

MCDOWELL: -- right, below 2 percent. Like 1.95 percent.

MIKE BLOCK, THIRDSEVEN ADVISORS: 1.95 percent.

MCDOWELL: The yield curve, shorter term interest rates are still above longer term interest rates which historically has been a signal of a recession.

What in the name of all that is real is going on.

BLOCK: Yes, that three-month (INAUDIBLE) is still above not just the two- year and five-year note but also the 10-year note. That remains inverted. And like you said it usually signals recession.

Meanwhile the S&P 500 made new highs yesterday. The Nasdaq and the Dow are within striking distance, something does not compute here. The data has not been horrible and it's not necessarily signaling a recession.

We had a decent ISM manufacturing on Monday --

MCDOWELL: Well, it slowed but it was still -- it wasn't --

BLOCK: It's still above. But it should make people nervous here, 51.7 is nothing to celebrate. It's above 50 but it's nothing to celebrate.

BOLTON: Best comment I heard is coming from a portfolio manager at PIMCO who said essentially markets are pricing in the best case scenario and the worst case scenario. Both are priced to perfection.

So she said there's a rally in risk-free assets and then a rally in risk assets and she said essentially the market is pricing in heaven and separately the market is pricing in heck.

BLOCK: So if you have a portfolio --

MCDOWELL: You can say hell.

BOLTON: All right.

BLOCK: -- where you're investing in stocks and bonds you're pretty happy right now. And again, there's some major strategies that are based on that. The thing is, where do we go from here.

Personally, I look at stocks and I say for the first time this year I've been relatively bullish all year. I look at these big tech stocks and I say well, maybe it's time for a little time-out here. We don't know how China's going to play out even if the G-20 went well.

Valuations are getting a little ahead of themselves. They're not ridiculous. But maybe there is a little steam that needs to come off. Meanwhile the bond market, the data -- the bond market seems to be in some kind of dysfunction. But is it really telling us to sell bonds here? I don't quite see it.

I think that's something that you can hold onto. Yields can drift down a bit. The curve needs to uninvert.

(CROSSTALKING)

MCDOWELL: Reduce your stock allocation but hold your treasury allocation.

BLOCK: Or make it more defensive. Instead of buying tech, maybe you want to switch into something like real estate. I'm not just going to sit here and say oh buy utilities and consumer staples because I think the fundamentals there are disastrous.

Utilities have had a nice run but someone needs to explain to me what the fundamental case there other than it's rate sensitive.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BLOCK: And it's safe. Nothing else.

BOLTON: I don't think that about China. There are -- Hewlett-Packard, Dell, Microsoft Amazon -- all considering moving manufacturing out of China. Google, Sony, Nintendo -- I mean this is going to have some long-term consequences, of course.

MCDOWELL: So the President, whatever his strategy is, like it or not, it's working. It is sending a signal to these nations that you should not -- these companies that you cannot depend on China.

BOLTON: Right.

MCDOWELL: And that you basically sold your soul in essence by moving production there and they're trying to diversify their manufacturing base. I would suggest --

BOLTON: Yes. Looking at some Southeast Asian countries, among others, yes.

MCDOWELL: U.S.A. U.S.A.

Coming up this morning -- Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue; New Jersey Congressman Jeff Van Drew; Valet Living CEO Shawn Handrahan; and from the Heritage Foundation Marie Fishpaw.

You don't want to miss any of those folks.

Our top story this half hour, crisis at the border, the situation at detainment facilities called out by one official as a ticking time bomb, in a new Department of Homeland Security watchdog report. The Office of Inspector General warning about dangerous over-crowding in border patrol facilities in the Rio Grande Valley of South Texas.

This on the heels of a federal judge in Seattle blocking the Trump administration from detaining asylum seekers while they pursue their cases.

Joining me now is former acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Tom Homan. Tom -- I'm sure you read this inspector general report. What do you make of it and what can and will the Trump administration do to alleviate this, what is very disturbing overcrowding in these facilities?

TOM HOMAN, FORMER ACTING DIRECTOR ICE: Well, look, these facilities weren't built for these family groups. And the administration made that clear for months. These are jails. They're built for mostly single adults, that's usually about 90 percent of what border patrol apprehends.

But when the family groups come across, it's either detain them longer to make sure you know who they are before they're released or just release them from the border which is unacceptable.

So the administration has asked Congress for months please give money to the Department and HHS so more family type beds can be found, more children beds can be found, which are built for that purpose. They have facilities there for the children, the medical care for the children. They just passed something out of the courts.

But it will help, but it's late. So all these pictures are nothing the border patrol can prevent. These men and women are doing the best job they can during a humanitarian crisis without any assistance from Congress for months.

MCDOWELL: I want to go through the numbers because the numbers are staggering and the report is disturbing and anybody who reads it would be upset about it.

But the question is what's going to be done about it. More than 332,000 migrants traveling as families have been arrested at the border since the start of the last fiscal year in October. That is more than any other full year. A 56,000 unaccompanied children have crossed the border illegally since October.

If you go back and look at -- compare that to the deportation numbers -- 332,000 migrant families, President Obama, his peak in deportations was only a little bit more than 400,000. And this is October, just October not even a full fiscal year.

So in terms of the number of families coming in, in the current year, will top the number of deportations, even a record during the Obama administration. So how would this money -- is this money enough, this $4.6 billion, Tom, that was approved last week by the House and the Senate and by President Trump. Is more money going to be needed at the border?

HOMAN: Well, absolutely. This money will douse the flames for now. But if you notice, that bill did not really address the enforcement component of all this. Without interior enforcement, you got no border security.

And you're right. The numbers are staggering. Back during the Obama administration when the family numbers were less than half of this --

MCDOWELL: Right.

HOMAN: -- we built 3,000 family detention beds. We built the facilities for the unaccompanied children that came across, the so-called (INAUDIBLE). All that was done in FY14 and 15 when numbers were half this.

But the leadership for the Democratic Party on the Hill still does not recognize this as a crisis at the level it actually is.

So the money will help. But there's going to be more money to be needed. Because there needs to be interior enforcement. I've said for months on this network, those families and adults that came across, they had due process at great taxpayer expense, billions of dollars spent on the whole system. When the federal judge orders them to leave, they must leave.

In FY15 I did this. And we did a nation wide operation and the border numbers plummeted after we did it because we showed there's a consequence and deterrence to committing immigration fraud.

MCDOWELL: Well, the President has promised raids, interior raids to basically get people out of the country who have been through due process. Do you think that happens, because it's --

HOMAN: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: -- been delayed.

HOMAN: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: And again, certainly the leadership in a lot of these cities is pushing back on that like Chicago, for example.

HOMAN: Well, it's a sanctuary city, right.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HOMAN: Either there's a rule of law or there isn't. I mean if a federal judge comes out with an order says you must leave, if the order is not carried out, if that order doesn't mean anything, there's no integrity in the entire system.

Just open the border up, let everybody come in because there's no consequence, no return. And I'll say this. Look, I've done this for 34 years. It's unfortunate and it's sad. It is. But it's a either that or open borders. We can't have both.

So I think the President has the right agenda. I think that nationwide operations needs to happen. Of course, the left's going to show pictures of children crying and women being arrested. But the other option is no border.

MCDOWELL: Well, there's certainly -- and I said this yesterday, with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and she makes this trip to the border and part of her accusations were people being told -- women being told to drink out of the toilet. But this woman did not -- Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez did not vote for this aid. She voted no on this humanitarian aid. And Speaker Pelosi knew that something needed to be done and she was not pushed and not dominated by the far left past of her Democratic caucus.

HOMAN: Ocasio-Cortez lost all credibility. No one's making anything anybody drink out of a toilet. If you look at the commode in these detention centers they same we have in ICES, you have a commode, on top there's a sink.

MCDOWELL: I don't want to debate what she said and what she didn't say. I know what the numbers speak. And she didn't vote for that $4.6 billion in aid. And she -- for whatever reason, she said that she talked to her constituents and they told her that they didn't -- that they didn't want her to vote for it.

CLEARY: Well, if I can just hop in here, I think it was just last week when the employees at Wayfair were infuriated that they were purchasing beds for facilities. There's this very -- I can't understand the logic when you don't vote for the funding, when you think we shouldn't purchase beds. We are dealing with a crisis and if we are attempting to address it in a humanitarian way, w can't have leaders in the party now sort of dictating a narrative that doesn't make sense to solve the problem.

MCDOWELL: Well, the leader of the Democratic Party pushed for the aid.

HOMAN: Well look, the leaders --

CLEARY: The social media leaders and AOC --

MCDOWELL: You need to give her credit for that.

HOMAN: First of all, I give Nancy Pelosi no credit because she never came to the table during this crisis. 31 percent of women are being raped making this trip. Children are dying. And I've said for months. They're going to continue to die as long as they keep loopholes open.

Nancy Pelosi only came to the table when she heard President Trump is going to enforce law in the interior United States and remove people that had final orders. That's when she came to the table, to protect illegal immigrants who had due process in the country.

That's what turned her around to come to the table. Not the deaths, not the rapes, none of that brought her to the table.

MCDOWELL: Do you think that a lot -- like Senator Lindsey Graham has a bill, and it was the William Wilburforst (ph) Child Trafficking Act from lat3 2008, before President Obama was inaugurated in January '09 that basically opened the door for children to--- basically encouraged unaccompanied minors to be sent here because it makes it more difficult to deport them and to send them back to their home countries if they're noncontiguous with the U.S.

Among the things Senator Graham wants to fix that. Is there any chance between now and the election next year that something on immigration is tweaked and fixed and the holes closed.

HOMAN: I hope so but I'm pessimistic. I think Lindsey Graham's bill works. The TVPRA had a really good purpose to protect kids form trafficking but you're right. They've used that as a loophole to come across the country.

But one thing people aren't talking about, when did these families start coming? FY13. What happened in FY 12? DACA. These family groups coming across now are your next DACA population as these children were brought to the country no fault of their own. That's when this all started.

MCDOWELL: And Tom, part of the problem is, whether these families are seeking asylum or not, it is the economy in this country. The economy is so strong, that it's giving them incentive to come here.

BOLTON: Well, the President of El Salvador saying he has failed, he took responsibility for that which thought was really standout.

HOMAN: Two things on the economy, it would be nice for the Democrats to recognize the economy is doing well and fix the system. If we need more employment in this country then fix the system and give the guest worker program. Let's just not keep bringing illegal aliens that bankroll criminals organizations and rape women and kill children.

MCDOWELL: And the jobs are here for guest workers. Tom Homan -- good to see you. We'll be right back.

MCDOWELL: A judge cutting a major award in a Roundup cancer case. Cheryl Casone has the details on this. Hey -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, the question by how much. A judge in San Francisco said that he would reduce the amount to $50 million or less after a federal jury awarded $80 million to a man who was diagnosed with cancer.

Bayer which bought Roundup maker Monsanto last year is insisting that Roundup is safe for human use. The company faces lawsuits by more than 13,000 plaintiffs in the United States.

Meanwhile in Austria, lawmakers there voted yesterday to ban a key chemical that is used in Roundup. Shares of Bayer are down nearly 40 percent from a year ago.

House Democrats are calling on Facebook to halt work on its crypto currency project, Libra. The five Democrats led by House financial services committee chair Maxine Waters wants regulators to look at concerns about hacking along with data and global financial security. Waters' committee is going to hold a hearing on Libra on July 17th -- same day as the Mueller testimony.

Ok. Crocs are getting a makeover from Vera Bradley. The company has teamed up with Vera Bradley to create some new designs for the clogs popular with boaters and nurses everywhere. The new shoes go for between $40 and $50. They're available in-store and online.

Dagen -- I know you want them now. You better hurry. They're selling out.

MCDOWELL: I think that you kind of have to own your ugliness and Crocs are ugly, so why and try and gussy it up, so-to-speak.

CASONE: Or just make them more ugly.

MCDOWELL: With some Vera Bradley floral which I think are ugly too. So ugly plus --

CASONE: They're unique.

MCDOWELL: -- ugly plus ugly doesn't make pretty.

CASONE: Yes. I'm good without the Crocs.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. Thank you Cheryl.

Coming up, helping America's heroes. My next guest's company unveiling a new program making life easier for our military members and veterans.

Plus Waymo getting the go-go the go ahead. The self-driving company given a permit to operate in one western state. Details ahead.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back.

As we celebrate our Fourth of July holiday, it's important to stop and thank the men and women who have fought for our freedom and continue to fight for our freedom.

My next guest's company provides luxury amenities for residential living -- amenities, services in say apartment complexes. And now he's doing more to help America's heroes.

Joining us now, Valley Living president and CEO, Shawn Handrahan. Shawn -- tell us about what you're doing for veterans.

SHAWN HANDRAHAN, CEO, VALLEY LIVING: Yes. So we -- the genesis of the program started about four years ago. I had a meeting with former Congressman Jeff Miller -- former congressman Jeff Miller and Blackstone and New Mountain Capital and look to hire more veterans.

We started doing that, went from 11 to a little over 300. Started sponsoring warrior games and wounded warrior ride to recovery, things of that sort and then we said we need to give more to our veterans that live in -- besides just saying thank you for your service we want to be able to give more in return back.

So we started this process to where communities and family members and friends could nominate veterans that live in apartments. And then we would go through a selection process and we'd choose one and provide a full suite of amenities where there's home cleaning, pet walking, package delivery, grocery facilitation to that veteran for a year.

CLEARY: My husband served in the Marine Corps. And I have to say, the veterans community and the people that we know there are two things you can't help but notice. It is a very difficult transition back to civilian life. And I think it's very difficult for veterans to ask for help.

I have to believe there's a tremendously positive response, especially for injured veterans, those who may have lost limbs, those who have difficulties doing their day-to-day tasks and the help that you serve must just be tremendously appreciated.

HANDRAHAN: Yes, you know, it's interesting you say that. There was a gentleman, I won't give his last name, his name is Andy that's a disabled vet that actually we selected him and he said it's kind of transformed his live because he and his family are dealing with so much. He's wheelchair- bound.

So we were very pleased to be able to offer that. But the other thing is part of our service, our waste and recycling service is a nighttime part time deal. And some of the veterans that are returning back that had seen combat as they assimilate back into society, working outside, unsupervised, at night tends to be a great steppingstone to bring them back into the workforce.

BLOCK: Shawn -- it's a great growing business. And you know, the secular trend is towards more rentals and multifamily. I'm looking through what Valley Living does and it occurs to me there might be a corporate application here as well.

Is that a market you've considered entering. It would be a wonderful way that you can expand veteran employment even more.

HANDRAHAN: Yes, we have. We looked at it. We have so much going on right now. I mean we just acquired a company called Torch Fitness. And we're offering fitness amenities. We support 1.3 million apartment homes every year.

MCDOWELL: Across the country.

HANDRAHAN: Across the country. So we've got 6,500 plus, associates. We have a lot of opportunity. I think that's something that we could consider down the future. But right now, we've got to kind our head down.

BOLTON: You mentioned the two private equity firms, was it a tough sell to them or did they see the value right away?

HANDRAHAN: No, they saw the value, actually. Blackstone committed to hire 8,000 people over the next five years through all their portfolio companies. And New Mountain Capital also did the same thing.

Fortunately for us, we were acquired by Aries and Harvest and they allowed us to continue to facilitate that program. So we're not near as large as some companies. But to get to 300, we committed to 300 by 2020 and we exceeded that by the beginning of the year.

MCDOWELL: So 5 percent of your workforce is made up of veterans, roughly.

HANDRAHAN : Correct.

MCDOWELL: Where do you see that number five years from now?

HANDRAHAN: Yes. I think as we continue to work with the local bases, we're based out of Tampa, to MacDill is there. I'm a Pensacola, Florida boy so Pensacola Naval Air Station. We're working with the bases of the Veterans Departments to be able to post those jobs internally. We would like to get it to 8 to 10 percent.

MCDOWELL: That's a awesome.

It's different growing up in the sought, in the rural south, and where you spend a lot of time in and around bases like eastern North Carolina for example, It's Fort Bragg, Camp Lejeune, Cherry Point. Seymore Johnson (ph) Air Force Base. You really have a different sense of the sacrifice. You have a different sense of the needs of people who are coming out of the military, who are leaving service and entering private life again.

And I encourage people to really get to -- to get to know those communities, people who are in service and who have served.

HANDRAHAN: Yes, absolutely.

Yes. It is a different mindset and you feel exactly the pain that they're going through. But we're a servant leadership type company and what better pool of candidates to pull from than veterans that have come back because they exhibit that relentless effort, flawless execution and serve at leadership that we try embody.

MCDOWELL: On that note, a shout-out to Tom Bryant, my buddy at Nascar -- who was -- well, he served. He served admirably. I'll just leave it at that.

Shawn -- good to see you.

HANDRAHAN: Good to see you. Thank you for your time.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much. Shawn Handrahan.

HANDRAHAN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Happy Fourth to you.

HANDRAHAN: Happy Fourth of July.

MCDOWELL: How are you celebrating?

HANDRAHAN: I'm going to be out on the bay, watching the fireworks in Pensacola, Florida.

MCDOWELL: Nice, I love it.

HANDRAHAN: Yes, we'll have fun.

MCDOWELL: Coming up healthcare in America, drug prices rising. Despite the Trump administration's efforts to keep them down. We take a closer look at what is going on.

Plus imagine a trip to Taco Bell where you can't get a burrito. Or a quesadilla, the fast food chain facing a shortage of tortillas.

MCDOWELL,: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, July 3rd. Your top stories at 07:30 a.m. Eastern.

Futures are showing gains across the board, a 49 point gain on the Dow Futures. But watch the S&P, it's up more than six points. The S&P after closing at an all-time high for the second day in a row. The NASDAQ and the Dow also gaining yesterday.

In Europe, we have some buying across the board in England, France and Germany. But it was a completely different story in Asia overnight. Red across the board as hopes of a U.S.-China trade deal, we got the truce, we're starting to make some phone calls back and forth. Lighthizer and Liu He from China trading some phone calls there, but where do we go from here? We have losses across the board in Asia.

Jim Beam up in flames, a major fire at Jim Beam's Kentucky bourbon warehouse, the latest on that blaze ahead in Woodford County, Kentucky.

No driver needed, Waymo self-driving cars now allowed to carry passengers, but there is a catch.

And a tortilla shortage at Taco Bell, what is behind this crisis?

And it's not too late to book a trip for the holiday weekend, where you can find some last minute deals, coming up.

To our top story this half hour, healthcare in America, a federal appeals court rejecting a request for a delay in next week's hearing on the constitutionality of President Obama's healthcare law.

Joining me now, director of Domestic Policy Studies at The Heritage Foundation, Marie Fishpaw. Marie, what do you make of this decision and what's going to come out of this hearing?

MARIE FISHPAW, DIRECTOR OF DOMESTIC POLICY STUDIES, THE HERITAGE FOUNDATION: Well, no matter what happens with next week's hearing, Obamacare is not going to change any time in the near future. So if you are getting your benefits from Obamacare right now, nothing is going to change for the foreseeable future. This court case has a while to go, it's going to wind its way through the legal system and may well end up at the Supreme Court.

(INAUDIBLE) The most useful thing about next week's developments is that it's a good reminder for all of us that Congress is going to eventually have to come back to health reform and deal with it, because only they can really tackle some of the real reasons that costs have gone up so much and choices have gone down for consumers under Obamacare.

MCDOWELL: What's going to happen, do you think, because this is a debate that's playing out in the race for the Democratic nomination for president, where you have some individuals, paltry few willing to raise their hand on a debate stage and say, I want to take private insurance away from 180 million people. But nevertheless, a lot of talk about a public option in the Affordable Care Act. How do you see the fix playing out in the next year, next two years, for Obamacare?

FISHPAW: Well, the left has made it really clear that they have their preferred solution to Obamacare. They'd like to move on as well. And replace it with a government-run program for all of us, and that outlaws our private health insurance. Those somewhat to the right of that would like to do similar things that would end up in my view getting us to the same place, just more slowly.

And the public option is, these are all options that double down on the same recipe as we've seen that have led to higher costs, fewer choices for consumers. So the conservatives need to come up with an alternative that speaks well to those real concerns by Americans and conservatives have been working to do just that over the last few years. We've come up with a proposal that would lower costs by 30 percent while increasing private coverage.

MICHAEL BLOCK, MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: Hi, Marie, it's Mike Block here. You know, a lot -- a lot of what we hear from Republican Party is really based upon this repeal and replace. And we never quiet hear the replace part of that. So you know, the solutions that you're speaking of here, you know, what does that really entail? Is it a repeal and replace or is it -- is it making adjustments to ACA? You know, can that poss -- can that work under, you know, what we're seeing here?

FISHPAW: I think it can work. The -- real -- one of the reasons costs have gone up so much in recent years is that Obama gives insurance companies and more taxpayer dollar every time they raise prices which is a real recipe for the kind of cost increases and choice decreases we've seen.

So, one of the things that needs to be done is to address that. The Trump administration is taking all the steps within their power that they can to provide relief now. And that's leading to real cost reductions in some states that have gotten waivers from some of the more rigorous Obamacare mandates. So we've seen costs come down in those states, coverage go up, all through tools that help protect pre-existing conditions.

So we need Congress to do more to enable some of the relief that's already been put in place in smaller ways by the Trump administration.

MCDOWELL: What about -- (INAUDIBLE) what are some of the other things that the Trump administration has done to basically open the insurance market to more individuals?

FISHPAW: Well, they've done a lot to increase choices. Doing things that will re-lead to lower costs, both for individuals and hopefully down the road for more people, even if they aren't in those plans.

One of the biggest steps they took recently was a new regulation that came out in the last couple weeks that allows employers to offer effectively defined contribution to health contri -- health plans rather than defined benefits. So people can buy the plan that makes sense for them rather than having their employer do it, buy it for them. This is really going to help small businesses who may not be able to afford to offer the Obamacare plans that have such expensive premiums on the market today.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Marie, if there were one change and I heard that you said, Congress needs to be more involved, but if there were one change that you could just magically wave a wand and have in place in the next 30 days, what would it be?

FISHPAW: It would be to shift the notion that there is one change that can solve the problem.

BOLTON: All right, touche.

MCDOWELL: She just stabbed you --

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: I want the information.

MCDOWELL: No, I'm just -- I'm just kidding. But it's -- but again, that's how these Democrats are selling their idea of -- they call it Medicare for All but it's not Medicare for anybody. It gets rid of Medicare, it gets rid of private insurance in this country. But there -- but that is the messaging, is oh, dealing with the health insurance market is so difficult. Let me, Elizabeth Warren, take that on for you. I'll make decisions about your coverage, what you -- what health services you'll get, what health services you'll want. That's the messaging.

FISHPAW: Right. And I -- that's good messaging, because in the sense that Americans are frustrated and we're right to be frustrated with many aspects of our healthcare system. You know, costs are too high. We don't perceive we're getting value. And there's so much paperwork and red tape that we have to deal with. And it's frustrating to patients and it's frustrating to doctors.

But the answer to that is not more of the same reasons that created our frustrations in the first place which is misappropriate government regulation and financing of the system. We really need to peel away the layers of the onion if you will, that have led to the mess we're in and end up with a place that really empowers patients and doctors to work directly together on the provision of their healthcare.

BOLTON: Well, won't insurance companies have a problem with that?

FISHPAW: Well, insurance companies do benefit from the current financing model that we have. But I think that at the end of the day, putting people in charge of their healthcare decisions will end up in a -- in a similar -- end up in a more robust market where costs can come down and people can buy the right plans that work for them.

MCDOWELL: I wanted to ask you a quick question if we can go back to that, and I'm doing my T.V. anchor best in the teleprompter. Prescription drug prices are up 10.5 percent over the last six months, this is according to Rx Savings Solutions, despite pressure from the Trump administration and Congress to lower these prices. What's going on here, Marie?

FISHPAW: Well, I mean, the first thing is Congress and the administration is right to be looking at rising prescription drug costs, just like all rising healthcare costs. It is a major point of frustration for consumers in part because we don't really know what's going on or why things are that the prices are moving around the way they are.

But it's really important that policy makers who are taking a really hard look at this continue to try to figure out the root causes for why we ended up in this situation. And a lot of it has to do with misregulation after misregulation from the government, applied onto a situation where the real signals of the market can get distorted.

So, the more that the policy makers can take a hard look at what's happening there, the more I think they can figure out how to get the incentives right to reverse the situation.

MCDOWELL: Marie Fishpaw, thanks so much for being here. Great to see you. Have a happy fourth.

FISHPAW: Thank you, you too.

MCDOWELL: Come back soon. Coming up, Waymo getting the go ahead, the self-driving company giving a perm -- given a permit to shuttle passengers. The rules it needs to follow, however.

Plus, thinking of the beach, the top travel deals as Americans get ready to celebrate the fourth. Live from Lido Beach, New York.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back to MORNINGS WITH MARIA. I'm Cheryl Casone with some headlines we're watching.

Multiple crews are fighting a major fire at a Jim Beam warehouse in Kentucky. These flames as you can see happening overnight to barrel warehouses is at Jim Beam aging facility, caught fire. It started late last night and the fire is still burning. The facility holds about 45,000 barrels of bourbon, two buildings are damaged, but so far no one is hurt. The cause of that fire hasn't been identified. But it may have been sparked by lightning.

Well, Waymo's gotten the green light from California regulators to start carrying people in its self-driving cars. The pilot program going to allow employees and guests to use the service. The passengers won't get charged for the ride and there is going to be a test driver behind the wheel. Approval of the three-year permit, a major step forward in Waymo's plans to launch a commercial service. Waymo a unit of Google parent Alphabet, Alphabet is up a half a percent in the premarket.

Finally this, Taco Bell has been struck by a major tortilla shortage. And because of this, Taco Bell restaurants are temporarily reducing menu selections because they don't have 10 inch tortillas which are used in the restaurants, burritos, quesadillas and other items. Taco Bell says the supplier issue caused the shortage. Taking a look at the parent company Yum Brands, up 20 percent so far this year.

Michael Block, the stock may be up but people are going to be down when they hear that there's a tortilla shortage happening at Taco Bell.

BLOCK: It's one of these things where you think to yourself, they had one job here, one job is tortillas. You know, there's like an old letterman sketch where there was someone like pranking people at the Taco Bell drive- in, going back saying, did you hear they're out of tacos here? No, so I mean, this sort of reminds me of right away. It's one thing.

BOLTON: I like this one job, you're like, come on, Yum Brands, you're not trying to like produce a movie at the same time.

BLOCK: Yes, it's this funny thing.

BOLTON: And Twitter is going bananas about this.

CASONE: It really is, that's true.

BLOCK: It's the high class problem or what? And you know, the Waymo news is exciting as well just looking at that. That is going to become normal technology's advancing. Of course the question is, OK, whose first? But you know, again, that could be something that's interesting for Alphabet's stock, just putting the stock ticker hat on.

MCDOWELL: And to your point, Michael, and that's a good point, they are going to have people in the -- in the driver's seat, test drivers as a backup. So, we'll see how it goes.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: I think it's a lot more reassuring.

BLOCK: They can go to the Taco Bell drive-through unless until they figure out this tortilla mess.

CASONE: There's the plan. Guys, thanks so much.

All right, we've got a lot more coming up, everybody. Celebrating America, millions of Americans are hitting the road for the holiday weekend. We have got the top travel trends, coming up next.

MCDOWELL: We're celebrating this nation's independence at the Malibu Beach Club in Lido Beach, New York. Lauren Simonetti is there with Conde Nast contributing editor Mark Ellwood with a look at some trip ideas, last minute. Hi, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi, Dagen. If you need some vitamin sea, if you get my drift, we have some options for you here from the beautiful beach club of Malibu in Lido Beach. Here's Mark Ellwood and we were chatting. This guy, the contributing travel editor to Conde Nast Traveler,

MARK ELLWOOD, CONTRIBUTING TRAVEL EDITOR, CONDE NAST TRAVELER: Yes, that's it.

SIMONETTI: I've been practicing. He's been to over a hundred countries. So I was saying to him, OK, it's July 3rd, I've got no plans. 50 million people are basically travelling this weekend. I feel like I need to stay home to avoid the mess. And you say, no, there's places to go.

ELLWOOD: I don't think you -- I don't think you should give up. You know, don't be -- don't be dissuaded that so many are on travelling. They're travelling for a reason. And look, remember, I've been to a lot of places overseas but there's plenty of places right in our backyard. I think if it's July 4th, you want to celebrate America, you want to go to some all- American places, can I recommend somewhere that I would go?

SIMONETTI: Please do.

ELLWOOD: I would go to St. Louis. Because I think that arch in St. Louis, which looks like a boomerang, some giant threw from outer space, this big silver, crazy thing, was just renovated, $400 million, almost $400 million they spent on it to sort of celebrate America's history. There's a new museum, there's a great park, and there's a very good July 4th celebration around there. So you're getting sort of recent American history.

SIMONETTI: OK.

ELLWOOD: I would also send you to Philly because that's really for the beginning. Now as a British person, I should really recommend this, should I?

SIMONETTI: Love it, keep doing --

ELLWOOD: I was going to say, I'll take it -- I'll take it. Signing the Declaration of Independence right there, Philly really goes doubles down on July 4th. You get, you know, Betsy Ross will lead you singing happy birthday. Jennifer Hudson's got a concert, great thing.

SIMONETTI: There's also some trends that people are following right now. Whether that's glamping or weekending, or I call it camp nanny when you send the kids off to the grandparents. But there's apparently another name it, what do you know?

ELLWOOD: Do you know what I was -- I would say, we call it -- we call it glamping. Let's talk about glamping, glamour camping. Instead of camping out on grandma's backyard, why don't you take your kids to like an American safari? How does that sound?

SIMONETTI: An American safari?

ELLWOOD: What do you think about that? Does that sound good?

SIMONETTI: I'm on board.

ELLWOOD: Are you game?

SIMONETTI: Bug spray included?

ELLWOOD: You know, I think you have to bring your own bug spray but you can make smores. All of these glamping sites, you're sort of glamour camping. They basically want to get you to enjoy the outdoors without roughing it. So there'll be barbecue pits, there'll be places to make smores, there'll be lounge areas. There are lots of sites like this, they're very affordable. There's this -- there's a site in Utah, there's a site on Governors Island just off Manhattan. And in fact, not far from us in mountains, there is a site, so we can go -- we can go there afterwards.

SIMONETTI: So that trend is actually called skip-gening.

ELLWOOD: Oh no, that's glamping. If you want to talk about skip-gening, it's very interesting, that's skip generation travel. Get what I did there?

SIMONETTI: Yes.

ELLWOOD: So this is when grandparents take their grandchildren away without the parents. So the parents go, we want a weekend away.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

ELLWOOD: OK, I can see where you're going with this. And the grandparents say, I'd like some quality time with my grandkids.

SIMONETTI: It's great exercise for the grandparents.

ELLWOOD: Oh, absolutely.

SIMONETTI: Millennials are doing the week ending thing, what is that?

ELLWOOD: So, weekending, I think you've noticed, a lot of companies are changing their vacation policy. Often giving things like unlimited vacation, Netflix does that. So suddenly people have more vacation than they know what to do with. But they also sort of are a little hesitant to book extra weeks off.

And one recent survey showed that among millennials, 80 percent of them would rather do a whole load of long weekends instead of one big trip a year. So we're seeing hotels opening just outside big cities so you can drive into them.

SIMONETTI: You are full of ideas. And I wanted to get your thoughts on one more. I wouldn't call it a trend, it's actually a staple of how we travel. Cruises, how have they changed? Would you recommend them? Which ones?

ELLWOOD: OK, how many -- I mean, so many questions. I've got them all covered. We are obsessed with cruises right now. We've got a brand new cruise issue on the East End.

SIMONETTI: Obsessed with cruises.

ELLWOOD: Obsessed.

SIMONETTI: All right, convince me.

ELLWOOD: So, I would say people don't realize that cruises are actually a great last minute travel choice. You can book up to 96 hours before you go, always book with a travel specialist, we called them travel agents in the past, travel specialist now. They'll give you the best price, a lot of ship board bonuses. But you can save up to 80 percent, that's eight, zero.

SIMONETTI: Wow.

ELLWOOD: If you book at the last minute.

SIMONETTI: And why is that? Because the cruise lines are thinking we can't really sail a half empty ship, so we might as well give a deal, fill it. And we know you're going to eat and drink a lot --

ELLWOOD: See, I don't -- I don't even need to be here. Exactly, that's why. In other words, they --

SIMONETTI: That's the way how it works, you can get 80 percent off?

ELLWOOD: Up to 80 percent off. But you'll get at least half off of those last minute sailing. You've got to be flexible. Remember, you can't say I want the penthouse suite on this ship no matter what.

SIMONETTI: Right.

ELLWOOD: And always check what the flight will be because you don't want to get a great deal on your cruise and realize your flight prices are crazy.

SIMONETTI: Right, but here in New York, you can just go straight to a -- to the -- to the harbor.

ELLWOOD: I mean, you just jump on-board. Like that's perfect.

SIMONETTI: Dagen, any ideas of what you might want to do for the (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: I love all of Mark's ideas and tell him I said that because I always tell people before you go overseas, see America. See the west. Go to St. Louis. I was cheering when he said that. That's the Eero Saarinen and the Finnish-American architect designed that arch.

And if you don't want to go to St. Louis, you can just drive out to JFK because he designed the TWA terminal, the old TWA terminal out there which has reopened. So I love all of those ideas.

And Rhonda one of my favorite people, Rhonda Haynes, who works here, she's a camera operator, a film maker, she just went on her first cruise to Alaska. So that's another way to see America. Yey, Rhonda. Yes, so I'm not a cruise person, though, but I'll drive.

SIMONETTI: I still have to figure my weekend out, but I got information from Mark.

MCDOWELL: Just send them -- send the kids to grandparents. Lauren Simonetti. We'll see you next hour. Thank Mark, Mark Ellwood.

Jobs in America, were get the ADP report on private sector job creation, that's in about 15 minutes' time. We'll bring you those numbers as soon as they hit.

Jul 15, 2015( Strategic Legal Technology by Prism Legal Consulting, Inc.: http://www.prismlegal.com/wordpress/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> This is a live post from the Bloomberg Big Law Summit[1]. Please excuse any typos or errors in how I capture proceedings.<nl/> Session Description<nl/>

9:10 am Keynote Address: Ann R. Klee, VP Global Operations - Environment, Health ...fety, General Electric Company<nl/>A maven of the corporate law business, Brackett Denniston III, Senior Vice President and General Counsel of GE [called away - Ann is his substitute], has steered the legal department of his $150 billion conglomerate through growth, turbulence and restructuring, ranging from major acquisitions, to the company's selling most of its finance arm, GE Capital. In a keynote address, Denniston will lay out his views on what it takes to be a strong lawyer in today's changing business landscape, and what he perceives to be the most critical issues driving the relationship between in-house lawyers and outside counsel.<nl/> Discussion<nl/> Ann has a team of 1800 people in her organization. Will explain how GE has changed and continues to change. Then discuss how the legal organization changes how it works. And finally guiding principles for success.<nl/> The one thing constant at GE is change. The company has sold off many units, bought others, and invested heavily to become the software company of the future. (RF: There have been many articles about GE investment in the Internet of Things.)<nl/> As in-house lawyers, we face several challenges. The operating environment is complex, for example, 170 countries. Regulatory structures have become more complex globally. Cyberthreats grow by the day. Lawyering in this environment is simply more expensive.<nl/> Our outside counsel cost is increasing at faster than the rate of inflation. GE drives a very hard bargain with firms. Demands competitive bidding, shifting work to smaller and regional firms. Former profit centers for some law firms - specifically eDiscovery - are gone; GE has pulled that work in-house. To address the challenge of delivering legal advice, the company is transforming its culture and leveraging technology.<nl/> In 2012, GE launched 'simplification initiative' to drive down SG...osts. It was not just about cost reduction but also to drive support organizations to become more focused on serving customers, internally and externally. One example from recent past: required over 100 legal approvals for lease in Africa. Another example: completely different contract terms across divisions.<nl/> The law department has simplified contracts and streamlined compliance procedures around KYC. It has done other process improvements. Integrated legal teams around investigations, L...government relations, M...environmental - across business units. For example, investigations unit was able to hire very high quality investigators who know local markets around the world. Saving millions of dollars by insourcing and getting much higher quality.<nl/> Consolidating legal work across fewer firms. Had worked with >2000 firms. Now down to 40 firms in US. Over 600 in Europe to about 70. Reduced outside spend by about $60M from this convergence.<nl/> Being asked to do less with less. We must focus on what's really important.<nl/> The big tech disruptor for GE is the industrial Internet. We collect huge volumes of data to optimize performance of our industrial equipment. This creates new legal issues. Team has to think about privacy, security, and IP.<nl/> Law department must keep things simple. Focus on what's most important and doing that. Stop doing lower value work. That has been really hard for many of the company's lawyers.<nl/> The need to focus is an increasingly important lawyer skill. This includes project management skills and knowing what to focus on. Most of our work is not bet the company. We must look at process analysis, IT, systematization to manage most of our legal work to be more efficient. Using Spotfire to get real-time data on all legal matters. Helps evaluate efficiency of outside counsel.<nl/> GE lawyers integrate with the business, working closely with business teams.<nl/> Unyielding integrity is a key principle. Speed and efficiency are important but not at expense of integrity. Moral case is strong but so is business case. Every dollar on a bribe is one dollar less available for innovation.<nl/> In closing… navigate a world that looks very different than most lawyers are used to. Business of law today is more challenging than in the past. But this means for lawyers willing to embrace uncertainty and ambiguity, there are many opportunities. It's a great time for lawyers who want to be business partners.<nl/> <nl/> The post Critical Issues in Relationship between Lawyers and Clients - Live from Bloomberg Big Law Summit[2] appeared first on Prism Legal[3].<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.bna.com/big-law-business-summit/ [ 2]:   http://prismlegal.com/critical-issues-in-relationship-between-lawyers-and-clients-live-from-bloomberg-big-law-summit/ [ 3]:   http://prismlegal.com

urn:contentItem:54W6-3RK1-JC11-928N-00000-00Critics Blast Afghanistan Announcement; Facebook Files to Go Public; GOP Blasts Afghan Announcement; Semi-Truckin'2012-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:06ZLexisNexisEARLY START WITH ASHLEIGH BANFIELD AND ZORAIDA SAMBOLIN5:00 AM ESTShira Toeplitz, Jonathan Collegio, Penny Lee, Christopher John FarleyNEWSInternational020201CN.V34Critics Blast Afghanistan Announcement; Facebook Files to Go Public; GOP Blasts Afghan Announcement; Semi-Truckin'Ashleigh Banfield, Zoraida Sambolin, Barbara Starr, Christine Romans, Ben Wedeman, Rob Marciano, Lizzy O'Leary, Ed Lavandera

The Obama administration is looking to bring an early end to the war in Afghanistan, and the GOP is blasting that announcement. Facebook is going to file for an IPO. Republicans blasting the defense secretary's announcement that the U.S. and NATO plan to end the combat mission in Afghanistan by the middle of next year. Mitt Romney, on the stump, saying this jeopardizes the mission there and essentially gives the enemy an edge. Leon Panetta did also say that an early transition to a training role does not necessarily mean that the U.S. is pulling out early. Big rigs may be about to get a whole lot bigger. Proposed federal transportation bill would allow heavier and longer trucks on our nation's highways. House Republicans are behind this. They like the idea, but the congressional critics are a bit worried about safety here.

ASHLEIGH BANFIELD, CNN ANCHOR: And a very good morning to you, everyone. Welcome to EARLY START. I'm Ashleigh Banfield.

ZORAIDA SAMBOLIN, CNN ANCHOR: And I'm Zoraida Sambolin.

We are bringing you the news from A to Z. It's 5:00 a.m. in the East. So, let's get started here.

The Obama administration looking to bring an early end to the war in Afghanistan. The GOP is blasting that announcement, saying not so fast. This is a bit premature.

BANFIELD: All right. Also, if you were looking at these pictures, if you're the police officer who is running the dash cam, what is that going across the sky?

I'm trying to hum that song. That's a pathetic effort.

Anyway, some people very concerned about the UFO possibilities here. We have the answer to what that fireball in the sky was.

SAMBOLIN: Is that do, do, do? What are you trying to do?

BANFIELD: I was thinking about that '80s show, that '90s show, whatever.

SAMBOLIN: OK, now.

All right. A woman wins gas money after she sues Honda. She spoke to us when she first filed this lawsuit. She said the car's manual promised her 50 miles per gallon. It didn't deliver. Can others cash in on her lawsuit?

BANFIELD: And Mitt Romney, fresh off the big win, talks to CNN. Our Soledad O'Brien saying something along I'm not concerned about the very poor.

All right. Hold on. Was that all he said? Or has he been eviscerated unfairly? We are going to get to the bottom of context and why it matters.

SAMBOLIN: But up first here, a war of words over ending a war. Reaction is pouring in now after Defense Secretary Leon Panetta announced that combat in Afghanistan will end next year.

This was on a plane to a NATO conference in Brussels. He told reporters, quote, "Our goal is to complete all that transition in 2013 and then, hopefully, by mid- to the latter part of 2013, we will be able to make a transition from a combat role to a training, advise and assist role."

BANFIELD: But this is not highly unexpected during a campaign year. But the GOP front-runner at this point, Mitt Romney, came out blasting this announcement, saying the Obama administration is giving our enemy an edge.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MITT ROMNEY (R), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Announced that, so the Taliban hears it. The Pakistanis hear it. The Afghani leaders hear it. Why in the world do you go to the people that you're fighting with and tell them the day you're pulling out your troops? It makes absolutely no sense. It's naivete. It's putting in jeopardy the mission of the United States of America and our commitments to freedom.

He is wrong. We need new leadership in Washington.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BANFIELD: From one politician to the other, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Buck McKeon, also had harsh some pretty words about that. We'll get to that in a moment.

First, to Barbara Starr who's live at the Pentagon.

First question right out of the gate: everyone's asking, Barbara, is this just too soon?

BARBARA STARR, CNN PENTAGON CORRESPONDENT: Well, you know, perhaps a hard reality check is in order here, Ashleigh. NATO has said the Afghans have agreed -- all troops, all foreign troops out of Afghanistan by the end of 2014. That is long agreed to. That is the reality. End of 2014.

So, what Defense Secretary Leon Panetta is saying is there will be a transition period before that, training the Afghans, just like we saw in Iraq. So, you have to start that before you leave the country, don't you? He's saying, basically, in 2013, they will start wrapping up combat. They will shift to this training role and stick to the NATO plan of being out by 2014.

The question is whether the Afghans will be ready for all this.

BANFIELD: Exactly. And then why is it we're hearing the critics saying this is a year sooner than we expected, and even the chairman of the Armed Services Committee -- and I know you know how strong these kinds of remarks can be -- saying this: "The committee has not seen a single assessment by our commanders that indicates they have any confidence in such a swift transition."

STARR: It's all -- you know, it's politics plus military policy, isn't it? You know, how unusual in Washington.

But, you know, you're seeing people select certain facts. The question is going to be this -- I mean, Governor Romney, still, what he says is what a lot of people are saying.

Will the Afghan forces be ready? Can they look after security in their country? Are you handing the Taliban a reason not to negotiate, not to come to the peace table and just wait it all out? Can you do something about those safe havens across the border in Pakistan in time?

All these are key questions. But the alternative would be for U.S. troops to stay in Afghanistan in definitely after more than a decade of war. Everyone knows that that is not a sustainable option.

BANFIELD: All right. Barbara, thanks very much for that. I have so many more questions for you. I'll touch base with you at 6:00 on that.

And I also to let our audience know that we got a great guest coming up as well. Major General Spider Marks is going to join us. He is the former commanding general of the U.S. Army Intelligence Center. He'll weigh in, as well.

And then, at 8:00, Soledad's going to go further on this. She's going to talk to Wesley Clarke -- not only a general, but a former presidential candidate. Wow, so politics and the military. This should be a great interview Soledad is going to have, as well.

SAMBOLIN: And it is 5:05. Minding your business now.

Stocks kicked off a new month with solid gains. The NASDAQ led the way, rising more than 1 percent, that's thanks to some strong earnings from the tech sector.

BANFIELD: And the big news might though have been Facebook, Facebook, Facebook, Facebook, Facebook. You probably saw it, heard it.

The company finally did the filing. We were waiting and wondering yesterday was the day. Yesterday was the day.

Christine Romans, you were the first to tell us at 5:00 in the morning yesterday.

CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes. And status update on the IPO is that they're going to file for an IPO. Now, we know.

We have a look, as I was saying, under the hood of this company. And we know how much money it made. And what kind of revenue it had and where that was coming from.

Basically, this is how it stacks up with the rest of the big tech giants. I mean, it made about $1 billion of profit last year. You can see that makes it a bit smaller than the Microsofts the IBMs, the Googles of the world when you look in terms of its income. Its revenue was something like $3 billion, almost $4 billion in revenue -- 85 percent of that comes from advertising.

So, now, we know how that is the bulk of the money it makes. This company has a lot to prove. There's so much Facebook hype now about going public.

Now, this company has a lot to prove. It has to prove it can grow that $1 billion in profit to something that matches the other companies. And the valuation on Wall Street, people are so excited about this. They're going to value this company very, very big. Maybe even dwarf Hewlett-Packard. And it's got $1 billion.

So, it has a lot to prove. When it gets access to all of the investors and that cash, that's how it grows, right?

But now, Mark Zuckerberg's going to have to answer to hedge fund managers. And he'll have to answer to people who are investors in his company. And so, it will be interesting to see how the company might have to change and how things might have to change for us because of that.

SAMBOLIN: So, that's kind of the downside, right, because it's a cultural change for them.

ROMANS: It is. And, you know, along with these filings, Mark Zuckerberg sort of wrote a letter attached to these filings and he talked about sort of how could code wins arguments, the engineering, the hacker way at this company.

I mean, it is really a singular kind of culture there. And a lot of tech companies have this issue. And they become public. And it's like, don't change us because this is what has worked for us.

But also, I'll tell you something so interesting about the letter with Zuckerberg put with this IPO filing. I'll tell you, it's very humble. "We often talk about inventions like the printing press and the television. Today, our society has reached another tipping point."

Ooh, the printing press and the television. So, Facebook has changed the world. Yes, it has. It has a $1 billion profit last year.

How is he going to drive that company so match that kind of language?

BANFIELD: That's 845 million active users on Facebook. And I heard a crazy thing yesterday. Tell me how crazy it is. One of these analysts said, you know, Zuckerberg might just come out and give every one of the users one share, just to be really different.

ROMANS: Wow.

BANFIELD: Weird.

ROMANS: Wouldn't that be interesting?

I keep thinking about the people. There's 3,200 employees who work there. Think of the people who work there who maybe took stock options early on instead of pay. I mean, remember Google and the massage therapist, there's Dell-lionaires in Austin, Texas, secretaries who took stock options in Dell years ago instead of being paid, because they didn't have cash.

I mean, so there could be people -- I mean, I think that's a heartwarming story. But for us, you were telling us about your son.

SAMBOLIN: Yesterday we had this -- I was telling Ashleigh, too. We had this full conversation about Facebook and how can he get in on the action? He's 13 years old. My gosh, what an opportunity for kids, right?

Because this is something they know. And to them, this is a big deal. And they want -- how do you do that? How do you get them focused?

ROMANS: You don't want them to get in the stock if it didn't pan out the way everyone thinks it's going to. But that is a good question because you want kids to get involved in finance through things they know, like Facebook. So, I think I'm going to find an investment club in this neighborhood.

SAMBOLIN: That would be very cool.

(CROSSTALK)

ROMANS: At 13 years old, he can turn into Ali Velshi. Ali Velshi was reading "The Wall Street Journal" at 13.

SAMBOLIN: There were go.

(CROSSTALK)

BANFIELD: My brother was doing fantasy stock book portfolios at the age of 12.

ROMANS: I love capitalists. I'm not one, but I love capitalists.

SAMBOLIN: If he turns out to be like Ali Velshi --

(LAUGHTER)

BANFIELD: I wonder what Mitt Romney was up to early in life.

ROMANS: I know, that's a good question.

BANFIELD: That's your next assignment. Thank you, Christine. Awesome.

I want to move on. Every morning at this time, we like to give you an EARLY START to your day by alerting you to the news that's not only just happening now. It's happening later. It's also developing now for the big story tonight.

In just a few hours, Attorney General Eric Holder is going to be grilled about the botched Fast and Furious gun tracking program.

Yesterday, Congressman Darrell Issa threatened to hold Holder in contempt, and then accused the Justice Department of a cover-up. In Fast and Furious, the agency just kind of lost track of over 1,000 different weapons that they were tracking after they were sold to so- called straw purchases. Some were covered from crime scenes, including one where a U.S. border was murdered.

SAMBOLIN: President Obama speaking at the national prayer breakfast this morning. We'll have his remarks for you live at 8:00 Eastern. Protesters are expected to be outside, including gay rights demonstrators and other groups who say the event is not inclusive enough.

BANFIELD: I was reading this thing in "The New York Post" this morning. Page six?

SAMBOLIN: Ooh.

BANFIELD: Yes. A crazy story in Page Six about --

SAMBOLIN: Waking up to TV tension.

BANFIELD: Yes, that's it.

SAMBOLIN: Was that the one?

BANFIELD: We talk about early reads. We read really early. And it just turned out, we were reading about yourselves.

SAMBOLIN: Yes. And so, it says, "A lack of chemistry is already plaguing CNN's new show, EARLY START, as it attempts to gain footing one month after launch. Hosts Ashleigh Banfield and Zoraida Sambolin," by the way, they have your picture in there, but not mine, "had expressed frustration about the schizophrenic nature of the show, a source said. Another source said they just don't gel. Banfield says too much."

BANFIELD: You're talking too much right now.

SAMBOLIN: "Sambolin doesn't say enough."

BANFIELD: You be quiet.

SAMBOLIN: Apparently, I'm supposed to be telling you that.

BANFIELD: So, here's the deal -- why is it you never hear about the guys on ESPN having catfights?

SAMBOLIN: Well, you never hear about that stuff.

SAMBOLIN: No, because it's more fun when you talk about girls having catfights, right? So, anyway. Love you, girl.

BANFIELD: All right. We got to move on. We got a lot more news -- a lot more important things happening in the world than that. But thanks anyway, "New York Post."

So, we got this most unbelievable scene that was developing in Egypt. Not what you think. This instead a soccer match in Port Said, Egypt. The fans rioted, hitting each other with rocks and chairs.

And if you thought riots got out of hand, this one has a death toll of 79 people.

SAMBOLIN: Unbelievable.

BANFIELD: Hundreds of others injured in this riot.

SAMBOLIN: So, witnesses say police did very little to stop the violence. Authorities are investigating the cause of the riot now. Did it stem from sports rivalry? Or was it politically-motivated?

Three-day national mourning period is now being observed there.

Ben Wedeman live in Cairo for us.

Are you hearing about this being politically motivated?

BEN WEDEMAN, CNN SENIOR INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Well, as any, everything -- with everything in Egypt these days, there is a political element to it. Now, just to give you some background, it was the Cairo team called Al Ahli that had gone to this stadium in Port Said to play against the local team.

Now, the Al Ahli team is famous for its participation in the political clashes that have taken place in Egypt over the last year. In fact, in November and December, they were leading the clashes with the police.

So, many of the members of that club, of the hard-core fans of that club, are accusing the police of just standing by and allowing their rival, the rival team's fans, to go after them with, as we saw, everything -- rocks, bottles, sticks and in some cases, according to eyewitness accounts, firearms, as well.

Now, many people here in Cairo are blaming the military for simply not being able to maintain law and order -- not just at football games, but throughout the entire country.

SAMBOLIN: Are they also being blamed for causing the tragedy? I read that somewhere.

WEDEMAN: Yes, there are members of Al Ahli team and their supporters who are saying exactly that. That this was the revenge of the security forces on the fans of the Al Ahli team because of their participation in those clashes. Obviously, we don't have evidence to suggest that.

But, certainly, now, we're hearing calls from leading politicians for the minister of the interior to be -- to resign and for people to go on trial for this massacre in Port Said.

SAMBOLIN: All right. Ben Wedeman -- live from Cairo -- thank you for that.

BANFIELD: It's 13 minutes past 5:00. We get a check on the top stories making news this hour.

SAMBOLIN: Leon Panetta's announcement on Afghanistan, expected to make even more waves on the campaign trail today. It came on a plane without the president yesterday. The announcement that U.S. forces in Afghanistan are expected to end their combat role in 2013 and continue a training role through 2014.

BANFIELD: After taking a bit of hit, Planned Parenthood has now raised $400,000 in just 24 hours. How all of a sudden did all that money come in donations? Well, it follows an announcement from the Susan G. Komen Foundation that they were going to pull their funding from Planned Parenthood.

Komen is blaming the cuts of congressional investigation over Planned Parenthood abortion services. The founder is denying it had anything, though, to do with political pressure.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NANCY G. BRINKER, FOUNDER AND CEO OF SUSAN G. KOMEN: As we move forward, we will implement these new strategies which will allow us to serve even more women. We will never bow under political pressure. We will always stand firm to our goal to end breast cancer forever.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BANFIELD: That is Nancy Brinker, who is the sister of Susan G. Komen. Nancy Brinker founded that foundation. She was a big contact with George W. Bush, as well. But this is a huge story.

SAMBOLIN: All right. And a California woman has defeated Honda in small claims court. You'll remember Heather Peters of Los Angeles. She spoke to us after she filed a claim against the auto giant because their Honda Civic hybrid didn't come close to getting the promised 50 miles per gallon. She's been awarded nearly $10,000.

BANFIELD: And you probably didn't see it in the Northeast or the Northwest. But if you were in Texas or Oklahoma, what on earth was that streaking across the night sky in those states? Check out the video from the police dash cam.

You know, I was going to sing some crazy song. But, listen, it was a routine traffic stop that caught this. But the FAA is weighing in on what that is. It is a meteor. That's the fireball. It was an actual meteor.

The reports came as far south as Waco, Texas. And as far north as Oklahoma City of people saying, yikes!

SAMBOLIN: So much more fun to say it was a UFO.

BANFIELD: Yes.

SAMBOLIN: Rob Marciano is in Atlanta with the national weather forecast. Did you see it, Rob?

ROB MARCIANO, AMS METEOROLOGIST: No. But that's striking video. It looks more like a UFO than a fireball or meteor. But I'll take FAA's word on that.

Another picture from space, actually, the dark side of the moon. Check this out. Ebb and flow, a twin satellite project, a grail that's orbiting the moon that takes the side we don't see. This is the dark side, the elusive one. And, boy, you see just how many impact craters are on that, especially down across the south pole. That, my friends, is good stuff. Thank you, NASA.

All right. Also, good stuff, you probably enjoyed it in Trenton, New Jersey, yesterday -- 67 degrees. New York City, 64. Record-breaking heat. This is going away.

The temperatures today will still be a good 10 degrees or so above average. Seventy degrees in Atlanta, 52 degrees in Chicago, some rain across parts of the Delmarva. Still some cloud cover today, at least for the most part this morning across Pennsylvania.

It's February 2nd. You know what that means.

Fog across parts of the South, hit the low beams across I-10.

And then blizzards taking shape across the high plains. Storms coming out of the Colorado Rockies, 12-plus inches possible from Denver across Nebraska beginning later on today.

Guys, happy Groundhog Day. Back to you.

BANFIELD: All right. That's when I said the Groundhog was going to be sweaty when he came out. That was going to indicate how the spring would be like.

MARCIANO: Oh, that's the new gauge.

BANFIELD: Yes, instead of your shadow. And, by the way, I was waiting for the Pink Floyd reference on the dark side of the moon.

MARCIANO: Nice.

BANFIELD: I know you're old enough.

MARCIANO: Yes. Very much so.

SAMBOLIN: I actually just found out how old he is.

BANFIELD: Can we say it, Rob?

SAMBOLIN: I was shocked. Do you mind?

BANFIELD: You're 14.

MARCIANO: Thank you. There you go. I like it.

BANFIELD: Thank you, Rob Marciano.

Ahead on EARLY START: A story from American Airlines, looking to cut thousands of jobs. Here's the weird thing. Why is American Airlines saying, oh, no, no, this is going to save jobs? What's that going to mean for you, too, when you fly? We'll tell you.

SAMBOLIN: And the Washington state senate passes the same sex marriage bill. Gay marriage is still not a done deal however. What happens next? You're going to find out in early read.

You're watching EARLY START.

SAMBOLIN: Well, good morning to you, Milwaukee. It's 5:20, 32 degrees now. But later, it is going to be sunny and 44 degrees.

BANFIELD: Very nice. And in fact, Milwaukee's a good town to start with because we're doing our early reads for you. Getting a look at your local news that makes national headlines.

This morning, papers from Milwaukee, as well as Seattle. So, let's start in Milwaukee.

"The Journal Sentinel" is having this report in its newspaper. Five hundred fifty people are filing sex abuse claims against the Catholic archdiocese in Milwaukee. They are all part of a bankruptcy proceeding, and there was a timeline, a deadline on this. The archdiocese has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, but it's facing these civil fraud lawsuits over its handling of clergy sex abuse cases.

Those cases are sealed, so we can't say who these people are filing. But we had the stories before. And the archdiocese is requesting that a lot of the claims be thrown out.

SAMBOLIN: All right. Moving on to "The Seattle Times." And we actually have a copy for you this morning. It reads, "Historic vote clears the way for same-sex marriage."

Washington state senate passes the gay marriage bill. It's a big step on the path to legalize same-sex marriage there. The bill now heads to the House where it is expected to pass easily, they say. If it does, the governor says she is going to sign it.

Washington would be the seventh state to legalize same-sex marriage. So, you know, in addition to 26 lawmakers who previously announced their support, two more Republicans joined onboard, Senators Andy Hill and Joe Faine (ph). So, overall, 24 Democrats, four Republicans voted or the measure.

BANFIELD: Something says it could be a Supreme Court suit. They always end up in that route. But an interesting story now.

SAMBOLIN: It's been a long, 10-year battle.

BANFIELD: Has it ever.
